headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being reco
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Steve Haymore, Investor Relations Manager for First Solar Inc. Mr. Haymore, you may begin.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the first quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors se
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the first quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. 
With me today are Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Widmar, Chief Financial Officer. Jim will provide a business and technology update, then Marc will discuss our first quarter financial results in detail and provide guidance for the second quarter of 2015. We will then open up the call for questions.
Most of the financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Please note this call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the Safe Harbor statements contained in the press release and the slide published today for a more complete description.
It is now my pleasure to introduce Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer. Jim?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2015 earnings call. Let me begin by providing a brief update on our prior announcement regarding our intent to form a joint YieldCo vehicle with Southern Power. Since Our la
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2015 earnings call. Let me begin by providing a brief update on our prior announcement regarding our intent to form a joint YieldCo vehicle with Southern Power. Since Our last earnings call, the 2 parties have filed a Public S-1 registration statement with the SEC for an initial public offering of 8point3 Energy Partners. Completion of the IPO is still subject to market factors and regulatory approval, but we continue to move forward through the process. Again, we cannot say anymore about the transaction at this time, outside of what is in the Public S-1 documents. Any questions on the subject in our Q&A session will be directed to the Public S-1 filing for answers. 
Now, for an update on our technology and manufacturing. Our module conversion efficiency continued to improve in the first quarter, with our full fleet averaging 14.7% efficiency, an improvement of 30 basis points from Q4. Our lead line efficiency averaged 15.6% for the quarter, an 80 basis point improvement quarter-over-quarter and 140 basis point improvement versus Q1 of '14. 
This improvement is the largest sequential and year-over-year increase in our lead line efficiency in the history of the company. Even more impressive is the recent performance of our lead line, which has reached a new milestone for modular efficiency of 16.3%. This is truly a remarkable achievement, which demonstrates the ability of our research and manufacturing organizations to execute to our road map. 
By late Q3, we will have rolled out these latest improvement programs across the majority of our fleet.
Slide 4 provides an update to our energy density roadmap, which we first showed at our Analyst Day last year and puts into context the advances in our efficiency. As we've discussed in the past, conversion efficiency is a narrow major of overall modular performance, while energy yield produced is a more comprehensive and superior metric. Energy density, which is energy yield per meter square incorporates several other factors beyond efficiency alone. These other factors include temperature, humidity and shade tolerance. Part technology has advantages in each of these areas over our crystal in competitors. 
As shown in the metric, our Q1 in the quarter efficiency achieved clarity with multicrystalline silicon on an energy density basis. In a of only a month, our lead line has now achieved an energy density advantage to multicrystalline and silicon. To put this achievement in perspective, when first traduced this metric a year ago at our Analyst Day, we had a significant disadvantage. But in the space of a little over a year, we have now erased that deficit. 
During the remainder of 2015, while early line will improve only modestly, our overall fleet average efficiency will increase significantly as the improvements are rolled out across the fleet.
In coming years, we expect to further increase our relative advantage based on the strength of our technology road map. Compared to our prior energy density road map, our expectations of relative advantage in future years has been updated. The update for the road map are primarily due to revised timing of our new technology implementations, which have been adjusted to minimize downtime from technology upgrades in order to maximize output, particularly in 2016.
Most importantly, the metric highlights the favorable competitive position we anticipate as we execute on our technology road map.
Given that all in new module efficiency enhancements are not created equal, let me make a few points related to our 16.3% production lead line efficiency as it relates to recent crystal and silicone record modules.
First, crystalline silicon competitors typically calculate record efficiencies using the aperture area of the module. We calculate efficiency on a whole area basis.
Our 16.3% efficiency announced today would equate to a 16.9% aperture area efficiency. Likewise, our 17% record module, which we announced last year would be 17.5% on a similar aperture area basis. It's also important to understand that our 16.9% aperture efficiency is in high volume commercial production and not in a laboratory. This new record also reflects materials and processes that are cost competitive and allow us to continue to lower our costs per watt. 
It is important to keep these facts in mind and based on our technology achievements, we feel that we are well positioned to compete with any commercial crystalline silicon technology available.
Turning to Slide 5. Let me discuss our capacity and demand outlook for 2015. This slide, besides illustrating our production capacity for 2015, more importantly highlights the profound impact efficiency improvements have on output. 
Since 2013, the year our production levels were at a low point, efficiency and throughput improvements have contributed to over 450 megawatts of capacity or the equivalent of 5 new lines. This is a key point to understand that our investment in efficiency improvements, not only improves our competitiveness, but also results in significant incremental capacity without building new factories. 
As a results of the improving competitiveness of our module and the continued demand we see ahead of the potential ITC step down after 2016, we are ramping our factories to full utilization. Also, as we indicated previously, we are adding 2 additional lines at our Ohio location.
We are virtually sold out for 2015 and we're increasing our contracted volumes for next year. We expect to shift between 2.6 to 2.8 gigawatts for the year, including shipments to developed projects. 
In the first quarter, we have shipped 690 megawatts, a new record for a single quarter. We are encouraged by the continuing bookings momentum as highlighted on Slide 6. Total bookings for the first quarter of 2015 were 422 megawatts DC against shipments of 690 megawatts DC. In the month of April, we have booked in additional 483 megawatts. As a result, our ending outstanding bookings are now at 3.9 gigawatt DC, an increase of 200 megawatts from where we ended 2015.
Achieving a book-to-bill ratio of at least 1:1 remains our objective for the year, but it will be more challenging in 2015 as some inventory was carried over from the prior year due to minor delays in shipments to projects.
The single largest booking since our last earnings call was a modular plus agreement that we signed with Strata Solar for 300 megawatts DC of deliveries in 2016. Through this deal, we've continued to strengthened our relationship with as well as extend our leadership in the Southeastern United States. 
Also, in the South, we signed an EPC agreement to construct a 100-megawatt AC Solar project and in a separate transaction, signed a module plus agreement with Silicon Wrenched to supply 70 megawatts DC on-site commercial and industrial solar power installation. 
This latter project highlights the value that First Solar technology provides for the growing number of commercial and industrial customers, peaking clean and affordable lower. 
Internationally, we continue to make strides in India where we booked another 75 megawatts AC of self-developed projects. This brings our captive project total in India to 200 megawatts AC and demonstrates the progress we are making in this rapidly growing market.
Finally, our utility scale solar development activities in Japan continue to progress as demonstrated by our first bookings this month. We expect to commence construction on our first round of projects under the mega solar program in Q3 this year. 
While ACcumulative volume of these initial projects is relatively small, it represents an important evolution from supplying modules to third parties in Japan to successfully developing and realizing our own pipeline. It also demonstrates that our technology has achieved adoption and acceptance in this important market.
Turning to Slide 7, our bookings in terms of expected revenue now stands at $7.6 billion. An increase of approximately $300 million compared to the beginning of the year. The balance increased primarily due to lower revenue recognized in the first quarter, resulting from constructing more projects on balance sheet.
While we don't provide details related to the gross margin on our bookings, we are seeing improving trends as we continue to lower our costs and see some stability in pricing. 
Turning to Slide 8, I will now cover our potential bookings opportunity, which have grown to 14 gigawatts DC, an increase of approximately 500 megawatts from the prior quarter.
Note also that the total potential bookings increased despite the strong year-to-date bookings. We are also pleased that the size of our mid to late-stage opportunities has nearly doubled from the prior period to 3 gigawatts. This increases our confidence in our ability to read our 1:1 book-to-bill ratio for the year.
Slide 9 shows the breakdown of demand by geography. Our opportunities set outside North America stands at 8.3 gigawatts or 59% of the total. Our transition is sustainable markets outside the U.S. is gaining traction as we are increasingly seeing the results of our investments in developing regions. More than half of our mid- and late-stage opportunities are now in international markets.
Finally, as announced earlier today, we have entered into a strategic alliance with Caterpillar to provide integrated turnkey photovoltaic solutions for distributed generation micro-grid applications. As part of this announcement, First Solar will provide a pre-engineered solutions package, including our advanced module technology, which will be sold under the Cat brand and through Cat dealers network. First Solar technology will be Caterpillar's generator sets and storage offerings will initially be marketed in the Asia Pacific, Africa and Latin America regions, beginning in the second half of 2015.
Microgrid provide value to prime, diesel and gas customers by integrating renewable energy such as solar power with generator sets. The target of opportunity includes in the 1 to 2 megawatt in locations such as mines in remote towns and villages. This alliance highlights of the ongoing global energy transition, where Solar's competitiveness allows complement conventional generation and is an exciting opportunity continue First Solar's growth outside of our core utility scale business. 
Now I'll turn it over to Mark who will provide detail in our first quarter financial results and discuss guidance during the second quarter.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Turning to Slide 12, I'll begin by discussing the first quarter operational performance. in the quarter was 500 megawatt DC, an increase of 6% due to higher module efficiency and improved utilization. Production was 22% hi
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Turning to Slide 12, I'll begin by discussing the first quarter operational performance. in the quarter was 500 megawatt DC, an increase of 6% due to higher module efficiency and improved utilization. Production was 22% higher year-over-year due to the aforementioned factors and the restart of 4 manufacturing lines in Malaysia. Our factory utilization was 87%, up 3 percentage points from the order. The higher factory utilization in Q1 was primarily due to less downtime related to upgrades. 
In the first quarter, we -- the average conversion efficiency of our models was 14.7%, which is up 30 basis points quarter-over-quarter and 120 basis points higher year-over-year. 
Our best line average 15.6% efficiency during the quarter and [indiscernible] increase of 80 basis points from the prior quarter and 140 basis points year-over-year. Also, as Jim indicated, our lead line continues to make remarkable progress as we are now running at 16.3% efficiency.
To put this in perspective, our module produced in our Malaysia facility at 16.3% efficiency has a cost per watt below $0.40, excluding sales-related costs. 
Turning to slide 13, I'll discuss the P&L. Net sales for the first quarter were $469 million compared to sales of $1 billion last quarter. The lower net sales is due to constructing more project on balance sheet, following our decision to pursue a YieldCo. In addition, the sale of SolarGen in the prior quarter, a higher mix of module only sales in Q1 and delays on several projects in the current quarter resulted in a sequential revenue decline. 
Relative to expectations for the quarter, net sales were lower due to several factors. First, the sale of a partial interest in our projected did not close in the first quarter, as anticipated due to delays utility to complete the required commissioning test. The sale will close in early April and will be reflected in our future results.
In addition, revenue on several system projects was impacted by a combination of permitting delay and the West Coast port strike. It's important to note that while these project issues resulted in a delay of revenue recognition in Q1, we anticipate recovering the revenue in earnings in the balance of the year. 
As we have communicated previously, our systems business can be lumpy from 1 quarter to the next. Therefore, it's important to look at the business through that spans multiple quarters. As a percentage of total net sales, our systems revenue, which includes both our EPC revenue and Solar modules used in the systems projects was 78%, a decrease of 14 percentage points for the prior quarter. The higher mix of third-party module sales was primarily related to shipments to India and the aforementioned project delays. 
Gross margin in the first quarter was 8.3% compared to 30.6% in the fourth quarter. The lower gross margin is due to constructing more projects on balance sheet in preparation for YieldCo, unfavorable absorption of fixed costs against the lower sales volume, higher module-only sales and a higher mix of lower-margin system projects. 
In addition, the sale of SolarGen in the prior quarter contributed to the sequential decline. 
First quarter operating expenses were approximately flat in $109 million. SG&A expenses were lower, but offset by an increase in startup expense associated with the starting capacity. Also note, Q1 operating expenses, including approximately $4 million of expenses associated with the launch of 8point3 Energy Partners. 
The first quarter operating loss was $70 million compared to an operating income of $199 million in Q4. The decrease was due to sequentially lower sales and gross margin
The net loss in the first quarter was $62 million or $0.62 per fully diluted share compared to net income of $1.89 per fully diluted share for the quarter. 
Turning to Slide 14. I'll now discuss the balance sheet and cash flow summary. Cash and marketable securities decreased by $506 million to $1.5 billion. Our net cash position now stands at $1.2 billion, a decrease from $1.8 billion in the prior quarter. 
As indicated on last quarter's earnings call, the decrease in cash was expected as we are constructing several large projects on balance sheet and in conjunction with our YieldCo strategy. Increased construction activities and holding interest and assets on balance sheet ahead of our planed YieldCo IPO will continue through the second quarter of the year in place additional requirements on liquidity. 
And then working capital, including the change in noncurrent planned asset and excluding cash and marketable securities, increased by $516 million in the prior quarter. The increase is primarily due to an increase in project assets and related activity and an increase in accounts receivable. 
[indiscernible] prior quarter by $26 million to $243 million. The increase is related to additional drawdowns on the associated with our project in Chile, partially offset by scheduled payments on our model. Cash operations was $418 million compared to cash flow from operations of $928 million in Q4. 
Free cash flow was a negative $466 million compared to a positive free cash flow of $858 million in the prior quarter. Capital expenditures totaled $55 million, a decrease of $18 million from the prior quarter. Depreciation for the quarter was $62 million, unchanged from the prior quarter.
Turning to Slide 15, I'll now discuss our guidance for the second quarter of 2015. As indicated in our last quarter's earnings call, given the announcement regarding the proposed YieldCo information, we are holding off providing full year guidance until after 8point3 Energy Partners' IPO. 
So much for the first quarter, our expected financial results for Q2 will be influenced by constructing projects on balance sheet, a mix of lower margin EPC projects and third-party module sales.
In the near term, this will continue to contribute to lower earnings as can be seen in our future guidance. In the second half of the year, we anticipated strong first half us returns are more normal course of business. Our financial guidance for the second quarter net sales in the range of $750 million to $850 million. Earnings of $0.45 to $0.55 per fully diluted share. Cash used in operations expected to be between $250 million and $350 million.
Note that our earnings per share estimate includes a nonrecurring tax benefit of approximately $0.40. This week, we received a fair ruling from the Malaysian tax authorities, which resulted in future tax benefits. 
Finally, one last point relative to guidance. The Q2 earnings guidance does not reflect any potential impact to our financial results from the IPO of 8point3 Energy Partners should that incur in Q2. 
Turning on the next slide, I'll summarize our part impressive improvements in our technology. Our lead line average efficiency improved to 15.6% in the first quarter and is currently running at 16.3%, which rates of 3% energy density advantage relative to silicon.
Our improved competitiveness continues to be manifested in our new bookings. We have booked 905 megawatts DC so far to date and with over 3 megawatts of opportunities, we are seeing continued strong momentum in our business. 
Finally, with the the filing of the S1 for 8point3 Energy Partners, our planned for our joined YieldCo with Sun Power remains on track. 
With this, we conclude our prepared remarks and open the call for questions. Operator?

componenttextpreview: I guess, the question that comes up quite a bit is there's -- the thought out there, solar panels or Solar panel and it's all of commodity. So how do you guys look at your technology improvements and differentiating yourself? And how does show through to
componenttext: I guess, the question that comes up quite a bit is there's -- the thought out there, solar panels or Solar panel and it's all of commodity. So how do you guys look at your technology improvements and differentiating yourself? And how does show through to financials and to valuation for First Solar?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So there's certain aspects of the business that are clearly commoditized and you can say sot of the panel to panel. But in reality, what it all comes down to is your customers by energy panel generates. And that's why we focused in this call and in genera
componenttext: So there's certain aspects of the business that are clearly commoditized and you can say sot of the panel to panel. But in reality, what it all comes down to is your customers by energy panel generates. And that's why we focused in this call and in general, we focus in our R&D and in our sales efforts to focus people on the superior energy generation that you're going to get out of the product. The standard face value wattage of the panel actually tells you very little about what the panel is actually going to do in the field and amount of energy that you are actually going to get from the panel. So in the real world of the today, hand-to-hand combat in sales, it's all about the energy generation of your panel. And the cost effectiveness of our product as compared with our competitors is very, very strong. So not only do we now have a product that has greater energy density than our competition, but we have a lower cost structure than our competition. So that allows us to be profitable and competitive in the marketplace. And that's how we think about it and that's how we focus on the terms of our research and development and that's how we -- what we focus on when talking to and selling to customers.

componenttext: Jim, I think you had mentioned your cost have come down to below $0.40 at least from a lead efficiency panels. Can you maybe talk about how that allows you to win this is especially with some of the utilities in the U.S. What kind of pricing you see in the marketplace today? And how competitive you are versus some of the word? And may be some of the technologies as well [indiscernible]

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's talk about solar-on-solar competition, first. So quite simply, having the lowest cost structure allows you to compete for business, capture that business at a more attractive margin than your competitors. It's a fairly straightforward analysis an
componenttext: So let's talk about solar-on-solar competition, first. So quite simply, having the lowest cost structure allows you to compete for business, capture that business at a more attractive margin than your competitors. It's a fairly straightforward analysis and formula. It also gives us pricing power to break up new markets. It also gives us pricing power to trigger the demand. The overwhelming impact on continuing reduction of prices on a global basis is increasingly utilities and commercial and industrial customers are seeing solar power as an attractive value proposition simply on its own. In the U.S., you have utilities that are increasingly moving towards natural gas as a large portion of their generation fleet. As they do with forward resource planning, fuel diversity, generation diversity is an important part of the formula. When you look at the prevailing prices in the market today, which dependent upon what region of the country can be from anywhere as low as $0.04 or just under that to as high as $0.06 a kilowatt hour. You may look at that on a flat basis for 20 years and compare that to additional costs exposure, even at today's low gas prices, the general view is that make sense as a portion of our total generation mix. So what you've seen in terms of this fairly large explosion of demand in the Southeastern United States is a result of that calculus, is a result of the marketplace understanding where pricing has gotten to and recognizing the value that it represents. We are seeing the same thing internationally. Just as one example, Dubai, originally had planned to carry out a 1-gigawatt program over a 3- to 4-year time frame. The first phase of that program, they were so enamored of the pricing that they receive -- that they doubled the size of that ramp and have accelerated the remaining 1 gigawatt to this year. So the -- we clearly, both in the U.S. and elsewhere, we've reached a price point where as compared with other sources of generation, both just on an absolute cost basis on a -- absence of commodity price risk basis and on a generation diversity basis, it's a very attractive offering.

componenttext: Actually I wanted to ask very briefly here, when you think about the contracting cycle to get you to in time for the ITC in the U.S., what's kind of the last day, if you will, to get the contracts inked. Is it the second, third or fourth quarter of '15 as you think about trying to get that full cycle to completion here and get those work backwards on that?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's pretty hard to generalize because it's going to depend upon the size of the facility. It's going to depend upon the jurisdiction in which the facility is located. That sets the sort of the permitting and code requirements that you're going to
componenttext: I think it's pretty hard to generalize because it's going to depend upon the size of the facility. It's going to depend upon the jurisdiction in which the facility is located. That sets the sort of the permitting and code requirements that you're going to have to meet. So I fully expect that on small utility scale plans, let's say, sub-20 megawatts in size, we're likely to see opportunities to contract volume well into 2016. On a very large multi-hundred megawatt projects, I would think that we are over the course of the second and third quarter of 2015, we're probably seeing the end of the opportunity to contract those assets. And it will be a pretty linear relationship in between those 2 extremes. So it all depends. Obviously, permitting a facility in one of the counties close to population centers in California is a more daunting task than permitting the facility in West Texas. So there's a whole host of variables that are going to impact when that cutoff starts hitting in terms of the last opportunity to contract and complete the construction within the IPC deadline.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that trend has continued to be down. The -- It depends a lot on installation. So if you're talking about contracts in the Western region of the United States, with high levels of insulation, we have seen prices between let's say $0.04 or just under up
componenttext: So that trend has continued to be down. The -- It depends a lot on installation. So if you're talking about contracts in the Western region of the United States, with high levels of insulation, we have seen prices between let's say $0.04 or just under up to $0.05. In the southeastern United States, they're a little bit higher due to the installation levels. But roughly, you are seeing overall power prices below $60 a megawatt hour for a new generation of any reasonable scale. And it's --  and everybody in the value chain is still making reasonable money at the price levels. It just reflects that we have all continued to drive cost out of the integrated plans on the module side, on the fixed balance system side, on the fixed and of the capital cost side. So we've continued to see those prices come down.

componenttext: Yes, so the conversion efficiency, we basically said that the majority of the lead line improvements will be rolled out over the next couple of quarters. So you'll see that happening here over the next, of course, which is consistent with how we saw the announcement we made last quarter on our 15 8% lead we can see that target impact the current lead efforts pretty well. As it relates to the next step function change in the lead line efficiency, there will be a step function by the end of the year. But as most these initiatives are we generally rollout a change. We've been trying to utilize across the field and then we look to the next around the road map. So we will see a little bit of a movement in the lead mine, but it will be towards the Q4 and a year before we'll see a dramatic shift on the lead mine.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the Caterpillar transaction, I think you can expect that on this particular transaction, the margins certainly initially will look like margin-only sales. It's possible that as we get into the partnership in the business, that could more over time
componenttext: And on the Caterpillar transaction, I think you can expect that on this particular transaction, the margins certainly initially will look like margin-only sales. It's possible that as we get into the partnership in the business, that could more over time and we can of participation. But to keep it simple and get transaction tapered, the focus has been more along those lines. In terms of the size, the potential market is huge and the Caterpillar dealer network is vast. And I think, for us to provide any sort of production or guidance as to what the volume could look like, I just don't think we have on enough visibility yet. We have to get out in the field and provide training and materials to and network of dealers. And once they begin to engage with their customers, I think will have that it represents is vast.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think about your first question, how much of the year-to-date bookings was actually be associated with projects that we'll construct and then drop down it to the YieldCo. So the best -- the only thing I could say right now is that our public filing is w
componenttext: I think about your first question, how much of the year-to-date bookings was actually be associated with projects that we'll construct and then drop down it to the YieldCo. So the best -- the only thing I could say right now is that our public filing is we've identified the initial portfolio and we've identified a potential growth of portfolio. We can't comment anything beyond that. But the current period bookings are not reflected either the initial portfolio or the of portfolio. So we have yet to determine based of the opportunities bookings for the first quarter. What they look monetization will be and we will guide that over time and make the appropriate decision when it comes. The expense question is more transaction with expenses in Q1. As you can imagine, legal tax, accounting, other one-off type of transactions will continue to incur those costs up until the IPO. Once the IPO launches, you shouldn't think of any incremental expense being incurred by First Solar. There will be expenses in management services agreement that will be provided to 8point3 Energy Partners, but those will be compensated properly by 8point3 Energy Partners.

At this point in time, we have the optionality, we will continue to evaluate for First Solar.

componenttext: A question on gross margin. I think, in implied guidance just like slightly below the gross margin. I just have a general question on gross margin going forward. I think, industrywide, we see something 15% to 20% on gross margin of the projects and you're probably have some headwind from the module. So a low to mid-double-digit, is that a good place to model? And also, if you could comment on where are you targeting gross margin on that drop-downs.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on gross margin, the gross margin is up, sequentially. We don't provide the actual gross margin. But if you back into it, it will show relative to Q1, we'll see a sequential increase in gross margin. We've -- if you go back and what we've stated histor
componenttext: So on gross margin, the gross margin is up, sequentially. We don't provide the actual gross margin. But if you back into it, it will show relative to Q1, we'll see a sequential increase in gross margin. We've -- if you go back and what we've stated historically, then the normalized margins for the business over time will be in that 15% to 20%. So that's not anything consistent with what we've said. Now as module cost continues to improve, we may see margins that are outside of that range, at the margin-only level. But I think it's probably safe to say that 15% to 20% is kind of how we're currently envisioning to evolve over time. At as it relates to expectations around assets into a YieldCo and expected returns on that, we have not made any comments in that regard although at this point in time.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Every time you have to back mine if you compare us to other industry participants, you have engineering procurement and construction business. You're not going to be able to do a direct comparison. We could take 100 megawatts of modules and sell the modul
componenttext: Every time you have to back mine if you compare us to other industry participants, you have engineering procurement and construction business. You're not going to be able to do a direct comparison. We could take 100 megawatts of modules and sell the module only at a very what -- looks like a very attractive gross margin. We can package the same modules into an engineering procurement and construction contract at a much lower gross margin percentage, but a much higher total gross margin dollars. And so it's very hard to look at our results in the aggregate and make a direct comparison to the other participants that are largely module-only sales as opposed to having a significant engineering procurement and construction component.

componenttext: There's a lot of optimality as continue to address the best use of 8point3 Energy Partners, and we will look at emerging markets because we have emerging plans in Chile right now and looking at the best path to monetize that asset. But clearly could be up at that says 8point3 is the best ultimate position of where we would want to monetize that asset. It's create somewhat of a competitive tangent so that others when how we can settle down and asset, there is a competitive tangent and there's a fall back in negotiations [indiscernible] because if we don't believe in markets willing to pay a proper returns for the value that they're getting from that asset, then obviously, we've got to a different path option nullity in our negotiations. That will evolve if you look at what we've included in the S1 is mainly U.S. assets, initially. However, over time, I think, we'll start to see some diversification in international markets.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being reco
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Steve Haymore, Investor Relations Manager for First Solar Inc. Mr. Haymore, you may begin.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the first quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors se
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the first quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. 
With me today are Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Widmar, Chief Financial Officer. Jim will provide a business and technology update, then Mark will discuss our first quarter financial results in detail and provide guidance for the second quarter of 2015. We will then open up the call for questions.
Most of the financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Please note this call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the Safe Harbor statements contained in the press release and the slides published today for a more complete description.
It's now my pleasure to introduce Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer. Jim?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2015 earnings call. Let me begin by providing a brief update on our prior announcement regarding our intent to form a joint YieldCo vehicle with SunPower. Since Our last ear
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2015 earnings call. Let me begin by providing a brief update on our prior announcement regarding our intent to form a joint YieldCo vehicle with SunPower. Since Our last earnings call, the 2 parties have filed a public S-1 registration statement with the SEC for an initial public offering of 8point3 Energy Partners. Completion of the IPO is still subject to market factors and regulatory approval, but we continue to move forward through the process. Again, we cannot say anymore about the transaction at this time outside of what is in the public S-1 documents. Any questions on the subject in our Q&A session will be directed to the public S-1 filing for answers. 
Now for an update on our technology and manufacturing. Our module conversion efficiency continued to improve in the first quarter, with our full fleet averaging 14.7% efficiency, an improvement of 30 basis points from Q4. Our lead line efficiency averaged 15.6% for the quarter, an 80 basis point improvement quarter-over-quarter and 140 basis point improvement versus Q1 of '14. 
This improvement is the largest sequential and year-over-year increase in our lead line efficiency in the history of the company. Even more impressive is the recent performance of our lead line, which has reached a new milestone for modular efficiency of 16.3%. This is truly a remarkable achievement, which demonstrates the ability of our research and manufacturing organizations to execute to our road map. 
By late Q3, we will have rolled out these latest improvement programs across the majority of our fleet.
Slide 4 provides an update to our energy density roadmap, which we first showed at our Analyst Day last year and puts into context the advances in our efficiency. As we've discussed in the past, conversion efficiency is a narrow major of overall modular performance, while energy yield produced is a more comprehensive and superior metric. Energy density, which is energy yield per meter square incorporates several other factors beyond efficiency alone. These other factors include temperature, humidity and shade tolerance. Cad tel technology has advantages in each of these areas over our multicrystalline competitors. 
As shown in the metric, our Q1 in the porter, lead line efficiency achieved clarity with multicrystalline silicon on an energy-density basis. In the space of only a month, our lead line has now achieved an energy density advantage to multicrystalline silicon. To put this achievement in perspective, when we first introduced this metric a year ago at our Analyst Day, we had a significant disadvantage. But in the space of a little over a year, we have now erased that deficit. 
During the remainder of 2015, while our lead line will improve only modestly, our overall fleet average efficiency will increase significantly as the improvements are rolled out across the fleet.
In coming years, we expect to further increase our relative advantage based on the strength of our technology roadmap. Compared to our prior energy density roadmap, our expectations of relative advantage in future years has been updated. The updates to the roadmap are primarily due to revised timing of our new technology implementations, which have been adjusted to minimize downtime from technology upgrades in order to maximize output, particularly in 2016.
Most importantly, the metric highlights the favorable competitive position we anticipate as we execute on our technology roadmap.
Given that all new module efficiency enhancements are not created equal, let me make a few points related to our 16.3% production lead line efficiency as it relates to recent crystalline silicon record modules.
First, crystalline silicon competitors typically calculate record efficiencies using the aperture area of the module. We calculate efficiency on a full area basis.
Our 16.3% efficiency announced today would equate to a 16.9% aperture area efficiency. Likewise, our 17% record module, which we announced last year, would be 17.5% on a similar aperture-area basis. It's also important to understand that our 16.9% aperture efficiency is in high-volume commercial production and not in laboratory. This new record also reflects materials and processes that are cost competitive and allow us to continue to lower our costs per watt. 
It is important to keep these facts in mind, and based on our technology achievements, we feel that we are well positioned to compete with any commercial crystalline silicon technology available.
Turning to Slide 5. Let me discuss our capacity and demand outlook for 2015. This slide, besides illustrating our production capacity for 2015, more importantly highlights the profound impact efficiency improvements have on output. 
Since 2013, the year our production levels were at a low point. Efficiency and throughput improvements have contributed to over 450 megawatts of capacity or the equivalent of 5 new lines. This is a key point to understand that our investment in efficiency improvements, not only improves our competitiveness, but also results in significant incremental capacity without building new factories. 
As a result of the improving competitiveness of our module and the continued demand we see ahead of the potential ITC step-down after 2016, we are ramping our factories to full utilization. Also, as we indicated previously, we are adding 2 additional lines at our Ohio location.
We have virtually sold out for 2015 and we're increasing our contracted volumes for next year. We expect to shift between 2.6 to 2.8 gigawatts for the year, including shipments to self-developed projects. 
In the first quarter, we have shipped 690 megawatts, a new record for a single quarter. We are encouraged by the continuing bookings momentum as highlighted on Slide 6. Total bookings for the first quarter of 2015 were 422 megawatts DC against shipments of 690 megawatts DC. In the month of April, we have booked an additional 483 megawatts. As a result, our ending outstanding bookings are now at 3.9 gigawatt DC, an increase of 200 megawatts from where we ended 2015.
Achieving a book-to-bill ratio of at least 1:1 remains our objective for the year, but it will be more challenging in 2015 as some inventory was carried over from the prior year due to minor delays in shipments to projects.
The single largest booking since our last earnings call was a modular plus agreement that we signed with Strata Solar for 300 megawatts DC of deliveries in 2016. Through this deal, we continued to strengthen our relationship with Strata as well as extend our leadership in the Southeastern United States. 
Also, in the South, we signed an EPC agreement to construct a 100-megawatt AC Solar project and in a separate transaction, signed a module plus agreement with Silicon Wrench to supply 17-megawatt DC on-site commercial and industrial solar power installation. 
This latter project highlights the value that First Solar technology provides for the growing number of commercial and industrial customers, peaking clean and affordable power. 
Internationally, we continue to make strides in India, where we booked another 75 megawatts AC of self-developed projects. This brings our captive project total in India to 200 megawatts AC and demonstrates the progress we are making in this rapidly growing market.
Finally, our utility-scale Solar development activities in Japan continue to progress as demonstrated by our first bookings this month. We expect to commence construction on our first round of projects under the mega Solar program in Q3 this year. 
While the cumulative volume of these initial projects is relatively small, it represents an important evolution from supplying modules to third parties in Japan to now successfully developing and realizing our own pipeline. It also demonstrates that our thin-film technology has achieved adoption and acceptance in this important market.
Turning to Slide 7. Our bookings in terms of expected revenue now stands at $7.6 billion, an increase of approximately $300 million compared to the beginning of the year. The balance increased primarily due to lower revenue recognized in the first quarter, resulting from constructing more projects on balance sheet.
While we don't provide details related to the gross margin on our bookings, we are seeing improving trends as we continue to lower our costs and see some stability in pricing. 
Turning to Slide 8, I will now cover our potential bookings opportunities, which have grown to 14 gigawatts DC, an increase of approximately 500 megawatts from the prior quarter.
Note also that the total potential bookings increased despite the strong year-to-date bookings. We are also pleased that the size of our mid- to late-stage opportunities has nearly doubled from the prior period to 3 gigawatts. This increases our confidence and our ability to hit our 1:1 book-to-bill ratio for the year.
Slide 9 shows the breakdown of demand by geography. Our opportunities set outside of North America stands at 8.3 gigawatts or 59% of the total. Our transition to sustainable markets outside the U.S. is gaining traction as we are increasingly seeing the results of our investments in developing regions. More than half of our mid- and late-stage opportunities are now in international markets.
Finally, as announced earlier today, we have entered into a strategic alliance with Caterpillar to provide integrated turnkey photovoltaic solutions for distributed generation micro-grid applications. As part of this announcement, First Solar will provide a pre-engineered solutions package, including our advanced module technology, which will be sold under the Cat brand and through Cat's dealer network. First Solar's technology, which will be combined with Caterpillar's generator sets and enter the storage offerings will initially be marketed in the Asia Pacific, Africa and Latin America regions, beginning in the second half of 2015.
Microgrids provide value to prime, power, diesel and gas customers by integrating renewable energy such as solar power with generator sets. The target of opportunity includes microgrids in the 1 to 2 megawatt range in locations such as mines or remote towns and villages. This alliance further highlights the ongoing global energy transition, where Solar's cross competitiveness allows it to complement conventional generation, and it's an exciting opportunity to continue First Solar's growth outside of our core utility-scale business. 
Now I'll turn it over to Mark who will provide details on our first quarter financial results and discuss guidance for the second quarter.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Turning to Slide 12, I'll begin by discussing the first quarter operational performance. Production in the quarter was 540 megawatt DC, an increase of 6% from the prior quarter due to higher module efficiency and improved
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Turning to Slide 12, I'll begin by discussing the first quarter operational performance. Production in the quarter was 540 megawatt DC, an increase of 6% from the prior quarter due to higher module efficiency and improved factory utilization. Production was 22% higher year-over-year due to the aforementioned factors and the restart of 4 manufacturing lines in Malaysia. Our factory capacity utilization was 87%, up 3 percentage points from the fourth quarter. The higher factory utilization in Q1 was primarily due to less downtime related to upgrades. 
In the first quarter, we -- the average conversion efficiency of our models was 14.7%, which is up 30 basis points quarter-over-quarter and 120 basis points higher year-over-year. 
Our best line averaged 15.6% efficiency during the quarter, and impressive increase of 80 basis points from the prior quarter and 140 basis points year-over-year. Also, as Jim indicated, our lead line continues to make remarkable progress as we are now running at 16.3% efficiency.
To put this in perspective, our module produced at our Malaysia facility at 16.3% efficiency has a cost per watt below $0.40, excluding sales-related costs. 
Turning to Slide 13, I'll discuss the P&L. Net sales for the first quarter were $469 million compared to sales of $1 billion last quarter. The lower net sales was due to constructing more projects on balance sheet, following our decision to pursue a YieldCo. In addition, the sale of Solar Gen in the prior quarter, a higher mix of module-only sales in Q1 and delays on several projects in the current quarter resulted in a sequential revenue decline. 
Relative to our expectations for the quarter, net sales were lower due to several factors. First, the sale of the partial interests in our last sale of Blackwell project did not close in the first quarter as anticipated due to delays in coordinating with utility to complete the required commissioning test. The sale will close in early April and will be reflected in our future results.
In addition, revenue on several system projects was impacted by a combination of permitting delays and the West Coast port strike. It's important to note that while these project issues resulted in a delay of revenue recognition in Q1, we anticipate recovering the revenue in earnings in the balance of the year. 
As we have communicated previously, our systems business can be lumpy from 1 quarter to the next. Therefore, it's important to look at the business through a lens that spans multiple quarters. As a percentage of total net sales, our systems revenue, which includes both our EPC revenue and Solar modules used in the systems projects was 78%, a decrease of 14 percentage points for the prior quarter. The higher mix of third-party module sales was primarily related to shipments to India and the aforementioned project delays. 
Gross margin in the first quarter was 8.3% compared to 30.6% in the fourth quarter. The lower gross margin is due to constructing more projects on balance sheet in preparation for YieldCo, unfavorable absorption of fixed costs against the lower sales volume, higher module-only sales and a higher mix of lower-margin system projects. 
In addition, the sale of Solar Gen in the prior quarter contributed to the sequential decline. 
First quarter operating expenses were approximately flat at $109 million. SG&A expenses were lower, but offset by an increase in start-up expense associated with restarting capacity. Also, note, Q1 operating expenses included approximately $4 million of expenses associated with the launch of 8point3 Energy Partners. 
The first quarter operating loss was $70 million compared to an operating income of $199 million in Q4. The decrease was due to sequentially lower sales and gross margin
The net loss in the first quarter was $62 million or $0.62 per fully diluted share compared to net income of $1.89 per fully diluted share for fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 14. I'll now discuss the balance sheet and cash flow summary. Cash and marketable securities decreased by $506 million to $1.5 billion. Our net cash position now stands at $1.2 billion, a decrease from $1.8 billion in the prior quarter. 
As indicated on last quarter's earnings call, the decrease in cash was expected as we are constructing several large projects on balance sheet and in conjunction with our YieldCo strategy. Increased construction activities and holding interest and assets on balance sheet ahead of our planned YieldCo IPO will continue through the second quarter of the year and place additional requirements on liquidity. 
Our net working capital, including the change in noncurrent project assets and excluding cash and marketable securities, increased by $516 million in the prior quarter. The increase is primarily due to an increase in project assets and related activities and an increase in accounts receivable. 
Though that increased from the prior quarter by $26 million to $243 million, the increase is related to additional drawdowns on project level debt associated with our Luz del Norte project in Chile, partially offset by scheduled payments on our Malaysian model. Cash flow used in operations was $418 million compared to cash flow from operations of $928 million in Q4. 
Free cash flow was a negative $466 million compared to a positive free cash flow of $858 million in the prior quarter. Capital expenditures totaled $55 million, a decrease of $18 million from the prior quarter. Depreciation for the quarter was $62 million, unchanged from the prior quarter.
Turning to Slide 15, I'll now discuss our guidance for the second quarter of 2015. As indicated on our last quarter's earnings call, given the announcement regarding the proposed YieldCo information, we are holding off of providing full year guidance until after 8point3 Energy Partners' IPO. 
So much of the first quarter, our expected financial results for Q2 will be influenced by constructing projects on balance sheet, a mix of lower-margin EPC projects and third-party module sales.
In the near term, this will continue to contribute to lower earnings as can be seen in our future guidance. In the second half of the year, we anticipated stronger financial results in the first half as we returned to a more normal course of business. Our abbreviated financial guidance for the second quarter is as follows: net sales in the range of $750 million to $850 million, earnings of $0.45 to $0.55 per fully diluted share. Cash used in operations expected to be between $250 million and $350 million.
Note, our earnings per share estimate includes a nonrecurring tax benefit of approximately $0.40. This week, we received a favorable ruling from the Malaysian tax authorities, which resulted in discrete Q2 tax benefits. 
Finally, one last point, relative to guidance. The Q2 earnings guidance does not reflect any potential impact to our financial results from the IPO of 8point3 Energy Partners should that incur in Q2. 
Turning to next slide, I'll summarize our progress during the past quarter. First, we continue to demonstrate impressive improvements in our technology. Our lead line average efficiency improved to 15.6% in the first quarter and is currently running at 16.3%, which creates a 3% energy density advantage relative to multicrystalline silicon.
Our improved competitiveness continues to be manifested in our new bookings. We have booked 905 megawatts DC so far to-date and with over 3 gigawatts of mid- to late-stage opportunities we are seeing continue strong momentum in our business. 
Finally, with the filing of the S1 for 8point3 Energy Partners, our plan for our joined YieldCo with Sun Power remains on track. 
With this, we conclude our prepared remarks and open the call for questions. Operator?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the margin for the projects -- our self-developed projects that will be contributed to 8point3, correct. Those are held on balance sheet and all the costs associated with that are on balance sheet. But still does flow-through into the systems busi
componenttext: Yes. So the margin for the projects -- our self-developed projects that will be contributed to 8point3, correct. Those are held on balance sheet and all the costs associated with that are on balance sheet. But still does flow-through into the systems businesses are third-party EPC business. So which generally has been lower margin than self developed. As anticipated, again, we're stepping into an EPC contractor or versus the actual developer, but the projects of the marginalization will be lower on that. And then, the other balance of it, obviously, is the margin that we are realizing today on our module-only sales are lower than, obviously, the future bookings would represent, given the improved competitiveness of our technology.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, the question that comes up quite a bit is there's -- the thought out there, the Solar panels or Solar panel and it's all of commodity. So how do you guys look at your technology improvement and differentiating yourself? And how does that show thr
componenttext: I guess, the question that comes up quite a bit is there's -- the thought out there, the Solar panels or Solar panel and it's all of commodity. So how do you guys look at your technology improvement and differentiating yourself? And how does that show through to the financials and to valuation for First Solar?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So there's certain aspects of the business that are clearly commoditized and you can say sort of the panel-to-panel. But in reality, what it all comes down to is your customers buying the energy that the panel generates. And that's why we focused in this
componenttext: So there's certain aspects of the business that are clearly commoditized and you can say sort of the panel-to-panel. But in reality, what it all comes down to is your customers buying the energy that the panel generates. And that's why we focused in this call and, in general, we focus in our R&D and in our sales efforts to focus people on the superior energy generation that you're going to get out of the product. The standard face value wattage of the panel actually tells you very little about what the panel is actually going to do in the fields and amount of energy that you are actually going to get from the panels. So in the real world of day-to-day, hand-to-hand combat in sales, it's all about the energy generation of your panel. And the cost effectiveness of our product as compared with our competitors is very, very strong. So not only do we now have a product that has greater energy density than our competition, but we have a lower cost structure than our competition. So that allows us to be profitable and competitive in the marketplace. And that's how we think about it and that's how we focus on in terms of our research and development and that's how we -- what we focus on when talking to and selling to customers.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Vishal Shah of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Vishal Shah of Deutsche Bank.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, I think, you guys mentioned that, your cost have come down to below $0.40 of watt at least from the lead efficiency panels. Can you maybe talk about how that's allowing you to win business especially with some of the utilities in the U.S. What kind o
componenttext: Jim, I think, you guys mentioned that, your cost have come down to below $0.40 of watt at least from the lead efficiency panels. Can you maybe talk about how that's allowing you to win business especially with some of the utilities in the U.S. What kind of further pricing you see in the marketplace today? And how competitive you are versus some of the other players out there? And may be some of the other technologies as well, such as wind and cold.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's talk about solar-on-solar competition, first. So quite simply, having the lowest cost structure allows you to compete for business, capture that business at a more attractive margin than your competitors. It's a fairly straightforward analysis an
componenttext: So let's talk about solar-on-solar competition, first. So quite simply, having the lowest cost structure allows you to compete for business, capture that business at a more attractive margin than your competitors. It's a fairly straightforward analysis and formula. It also gives us pricing power to break up in new markets. It also gives us pricing power to trigger new demand. The overwhelming impact on continuing reduction of prices on a global basis is increasingly utilities and commercial and industrial customers are seeing solar power as an attractive value proposition simply on its own. In the U.S., you have utilities that are increasingly moving towards natural gas as a large portion of their generation fleet. As they do their forward resource planning, fuel diversity, generation diversity is an important part of the formula. When you look at the prevailing prices in the market today, which's dependent upon what region of the country can be from anywhere as low as $0.04 or just under that to as high as $0.06 a kilowatt hour. We may look at that on a flat basis for 20 years and compare that to additional natural gas exposure. Even at today's low gas prices, the general view is that make sense as a portion of our total generation mix. So what you've seen in terms of this fairly large explosion of demand in the Southeastern United States is a result of that calculus, is a result of the marketplace understanding where pricing has gotten to and recognizing the value that it represents. We are seeing the same thing internationally. Just as one example, Dubai, originally had planned to carry out 1-gigawatt program over 3- to 4-year time frame. The first phase of that program, they were so enamored of the pricing that they received, that they doubled the size of that ramp and have accelerated the remaining 1-gigawatt to this year. So the -- we clearly, both in the U.S. and elsewhere, we've reached a price point where as compared with other sources of generation, both just on an absolute cost basis on a -- absence of commodity price-risk basis and on a generation-diversity basis, it's a very attractive offering.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually I wanted to ask very briefly here, when you think about the contracting cycle to get utility-scale deals done in time for the ITC in the U.S., what's kind of the last day, if you will, to get the contracts inked. Is it the second, third or fourth
componenttext: Actually I wanted to ask very briefly here, when you think about the contracting cycle to get utility-scale deals done in time for the ITC in the U.S., what's kind of the last day, if you will, to get the contracts inked. Is it the second, third or fourth quarter of '15 as you think about trying to get that full cycle to completion here and get those -- and work backwards from that?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's pretty hard to generalize, because it's going to depend upon the size of the facility, it's going to depend upon the jurisdiction in which the facility is located. That sets the sort of the permitting and code requirements that you're going t
componenttext: I think it's pretty hard to generalize, because it's going to depend upon the size of the facility, it's going to depend upon the jurisdiction in which the facility is located. That sets the sort of the permitting and code requirements that you're going to have to meet. So I fully expect that on small utility-scale plants, let's say sub-20 megawatts in size, we're likely to see opportunities to contract volume well into 2016. On the very large multi-hundred megawatt projects, I would think that we are -- over the course of the second and third quarter of 2015, we're probably seeing the end of the opportunity to contract for those assets. And it'll be a pretty linear relationship in between those 2 extremes. So it all depends. Obviously permitting a facility in one of the counties close to population centers in California is a more daunting task than permitting a facility in rural West Texas. So there's a whole host of variables that are going to impact when that cutoff starts hitting in terms of the last opportunity to contract and complete the construction within the ITC deadline.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: And we'll go next to Krish Sankar with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 2 of them. First one, Jim, can you talk a little bit about how you seek the PPA prices for utility commercial kind of trend either in Q1 or over the last 6 months? How has trend been? And if you can give some color based on the different geographie
componenttext: I have 2 of them. First one, Jim, can you talk a little bit about how you seek the PPA prices for utility commercial kind of trend either in Q1 or over the last 6 months? How has trend been? And if you can give some color based on the different geographies, that will be very helpful.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the trend has continued to be down. The -- it depends a lot on insulation. So if you're talking about contracts in the western region of the United States with high levels of insulation, we have seen prices between, let's say, $0.04 or just under up to
componenttext: So the trend has continued to be down. The -- it depends a lot on insulation. So if you're talking about contracts in the western region of the United States with high levels of insulation, we have seen prices between, let's say, $0.04 or just under up to $0.05. In the southeastern United States, they're a little bit higher due to the insulation levels. But broadly, you're seeing overall power prices below $60 a megawatt hour for new generation of any reasonable scale. And it's -- and everybody in the value chain is still making reasonable money at those price levels. It just reflects that we have all continued to drive cost out of the integrated plant on the module side, on the fixed balance of system side, on the variable balance of system side and on the capital cost side. So we've continued to see those prices come down.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: I have 2 of them. I'll try to squeeze both of them in here quickly. First on the conversion efficiency, what's the expected timeline for the lead line to become fleet average? Is it something that you expect to materialize within 12-month window? And then maybe related to that, any reason why the lead line starts to moderate per your comments, Jim, off these recent levels? And then the second question I had was on Caterpillar, the announcement there. Will the economics on those sales resemble module-only margins? Is there any potential recurring revenue from those sales? And then any potential quantification on what this could represent in terms of additional volume opportunity for you guys in 2016 in its first full year?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll let Mark tackle your first question.
componenttext: Sure. I'll let Mark tackle your first question.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the conversion efficiency, what we basically have said is that the vast majority of the lead line improvements will be rolled out over the next couple of quarters. So you'll see that happening here over the next 4 quarters, which is consistent wit
componenttext: Yes. So the conversion efficiency, what we basically have said is that the vast majority of the lead line improvements will be rolled out over the next couple of quarters. So you'll see that happening here over the next 4 quarters, which is consistent with how we saw the announcement we made last quarter on our '15, 8% lead line efficiency. As you can see, that's starting to impact the current fleet average pretty well. As it relates to the next step function change in the lead line efficiency, there will be a step function by the end of the year. But as most of these initiatives are, we generally rollout a change, we then try to stabilize across the fleet and then we look to the next step along the roadmap. So we will see a little bit of movement in the lead line, but it will be towards the Q4 end of the year before we'll see a dramatic shift in the lead line.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the Caterpillar transaction, I think you can expect that on this particular transaction, the margin certainly initially will look like module-only sales. It's possible that as we get into the partnership in the business, that could morph over time
componenttext: And on the Caterpillar transaction, I think you can expect that on this particular transaction, the margin certainly initially will look like module-only sales. It's possible that as we get into the partnership in the business, that could morph over time and we can have a greater scope of participation. But to keep it simple and get the transaction papered, the focus has been more along those lines. In terms of the size, the potential market is huge and the Caterpillar dealer network is vast. And I think for us, to provide any sort of prediction or guidance as to what the volume could look like, I just don't think we have enough visibility yet. We've got to get out in the field and provide training and materials to the network of dealers. And then once they begin to engage with their customers, I think we'll have much greater visibility, but I don't think we have it at this point, but the potential addressable market that it represents is vast.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as I think if I understand your first question correctly is how much of the year-to-date bookings would actually be associated with projects that we'll construct and then drop down into the YieldCo. So the best thing -- the only thing I could say right
componenttext: So as I think if I understand your first question correctly is how much of the year-to-date bookings would actually be associated with projects that we'll construct and then drop down into the YieldCo. So the best thing -- the only thing I could say right now is that in our public filing is that we've identified the initial portfolio of assets and we've identified a potential ROFO portfolio. We can't comment anything beyond that. But the current period bookings are not reflective of either the initial portfolio or the ROFO portfolio. So we have yet to determine based off of the opportunity set that we have and the bookings for the first quarter, what the ultimate monetization will be and we will guide with that over time and make appropriate decision when it comes. The expense question is -- we've incurred more transactional expenses in Q1. As you can imagine, legal tax, accounting, other one-off type of transactions. We'll continue to incur those costs up until the IPO. Once the IPO launches, you shouldn't think of any incremental expenses being incurred by First Solar. There will be expenses in management services agreements that will be provided to 8point3 Energy Partners, but those will be compensated appropriately by 8point3 Energy Partners.

componenttext: Just a quick question. As we move forward, I'm expecting seeing the pipeline to shift towards maybe emerging markets a little bit more. As that happens and you build a pipeline of projects outside of North America, in particular, and outside of OECD countries, are you going to start to hold back projects there as well? Or are those all built to sell for the time being?

componenttext: So if you look at the filing that we did, the S1 filing, there are definitions of qualified assets, primarily related to OECD type of countries that can be evaluated, and we'll make those decisions over time. If the economics look attractive and it's compelling to include into 8point3, we'll do that. If we think we can capture better economics by monetizing them with local cost of capital available, then we potentially will take that path. At this point in time, we have the optionality, we'll continue to evaluate what makes the most sense for First Solar.

componenttext: A question on gross margin. I think implied guidance suggests like maybe slightly below the gross margin. I just have a general question on gross margin going forward. I think industry wide, we see something like 15% to 20% type gross margin on the projects and you probably have some headwind from the module. So is a low- to mid-double-digit, is that a good place to model? And also, if you can comment on where are you targeting gross margin on the drop-downs.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on gross margin, first off, the gross margin is up sequentially. We don't provide the actual gross margin. But if you back into it, you'll will show relative to Q1, we'll see a sequential increase in gross margin. We've -- if you go back and what we've
componenttext: So on gross margin, first off, the gross margin is up sequentially. We don't provide the actual gross margin. But if you back into it, you'll will show relative to Q1, we'll see a sequential increase in gross margin. We've -- if you go back and what we've stated historically is that we anticipate that the normalized margins for the business over time will be in that 15% to 20%. So that's not anything that is inconsistent with what we've said. Now as the module cost continues to improve, we may see margins that are outside of that range at the module-only level. But I think it's probably safe to say that 15% to 20% is kind of how we're currently envisioning the business to evolve over time. As it relates to expectations around drop down of assets into a YieldCo and expected returns on that, we have not made any comments in that regard nor will we at this point in time.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other comment I would add is you have to bear in mind, if you compare us to other industry participants that don't have an engineering, procurement and construction business, you're not going to be able to do a direct comparison. We could take a 100 m
componenttext: The other comment I would add is you have to bear in mind, if you compare us to other industry participants that don't have an engineering, procurement and construction business, you're not going to be able to do a direct comparison. We could take a 100 megawatts of modules and sell that module only at a very -- what looks like a very attractive gross margin. We can package those same modules into an engineering, procurement and construction contract that's at a much lower gross margin percentage but a much higher total gross margin dollars. And so it's very hard to look at our results in the aggregate and make a direct comparison to the other participants that are largely module-only sales as opposed to having a significant engineering, procurement and construction component.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So there is lots of optionality as we continue to address the best use of 8point3 Energy Partners, and we will look at emerging markets, because we have merchant plant in Chile right now and looking at the best path to monetize that asset. That clearly co
componenttext: So there is lots of optionality as we continue to address the best use of 8point3 Energy Partners, and we will look at emerging markets, because we have merchant plant in Chile right now and looking at the best path to monetize that asset. That clearly could be a path that says that 8point3 is the best ultimate position of where we would want to monetize that asset. We've got assets in Japan that we're developing and we'll be looking at those as well in terms of what is the right answer to do that. So what I would say is, it's given us significant optionality. It creates somewhat of a competitive tension so that others -- when we get into having to sell down an asset, there is a competitive tension and there's a fall back position in the negotiations which obviously is advantageous to us, because if we don't believe in market is willing to pay a proper returns for the value that they're getting from that asset, then we obviously have a different path to choose. So that optionality will be helpful in our negotiations. So I do see that we'll evolve over time. Again if you look at what we've included in the S1 is mainly U.S. assets, initially. However, over time, I think you'll start to see some diversification into international markets.
