headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investor section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to
componenttext: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investor section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Steve Haymore from First Solar Investor Relations. Mr. Haymore, you may begin.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its preliminary financial results for the third quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the
componenttext: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its preliminary financial results for the third quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. With me today are Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Widmar, Chief Financial Officer. Jim will provide a business and technology update, then Mark will discuss our third quarter financial results in detail and provide guidance for 2015. We will then open up the call for questions. Most of the financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Please note, this call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statements contained in the press release and the slides published today for a more complete description. It is now my pleasure to introduce Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer. Jim?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. As indicated in our press release, we have issued preliminary financial results for the third quarter while we completed an analysis of the discrete income tax matter related to a foreign
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. As indicated in our press release, we have issued preliminary financial results for the third quarter while we completed an analysis of the discrete income tax matter related to a foreign tax jurisdiction. While Mark will discuss this matter on more detail later, I wish to emphasize that this matter does not have any adverse impact on the ongoing operations of the company. We are working towards a full and timely resolution of the issues. Now let me turn to an update on the business and the outstanding performance of this past quarter. 
In the third quarter, we had tremendous execution across all parts of the organization, which has resulted in strong results from a financial bookings and technology standpoint. Before further discussing these points, it is worth taking a moment to reflect on the progress we have made as a company over the past several years. 
In 2012, First Solar and the entire solar industry faced a period of disruption resulting from declines in unsustainable subsidized solar markets. At our Q1 2012 earnings call, we laid out a 5-year plan and identify key 2016 financial targets that focus the organization and create value for our shareholders. As we near the end of year 4 of this plan, with year-to-date bookings of 3.1 gigawatts, earnings guidance of over $4 per share and the strongest technology position in our company's history, we have to recognize the tremendous progress that has been made towards these objectives since 2012. 
With the vision 2020 plan that we introduced last quarter, we will continue this pattern of setting challenging goals and working to achieve them. 
Turning to our technology performance in the third quarter. Our fleet average efficiency improved to 15.8%, a 40-basis-point improvement from the second quarter. Our lead line efficiency averaged 16.4%, a 20-basis-point improvement quarter-over-quarter and a 210-basis-point improvement versus Q3 2014. A more modest improvement in the sequential lead line efficiency relative to prior quarters is a reflection of an intentional and temporary new technology implementations. As we have stated previously, we are completing the rollout of our technology upgrade across the entire fleet this year. 
In the first half of 2016, we will prioritize full production utilization in order to meet strong demands and then resume the implementation of new module efficiency programs thereafter. 
Next, we are very pleased with our progress in securing the business for the future. Slide 5 highlights our year-to-date bookings, which now stand at 3.1 gigawatts. With 2 months left in the year, we have already set a new annual bookings records and anticipate adding to this total before the end of the year. With at least 3.1 gigawatts of bookings for the year and projected full year shipments of approximately 2.9 gigawatts, we will once again exceed our goal of a 1:1 book-to-bill ratio. 
Our total 1.7 gigawatts of bookings since last earnings call are not only impressive in size, but also reflects some positive indications of utility scale solar demand in the U.S. after 2016. Approximately 60% or over 1 gigawatt DC of the total 1.7 gigawatt DC growth are projects in the U.S. that has commercial operations dates after 2016. Approximately 630 megawatts DC of this volume represent PPAs that have been signed with a leading utility in the Western United States and span across 4 projects, which are anticipated to commence delivering power into utilities late in 2019. 
As with other PPA awards, these projects are subject to utility commission approval. More details will be made public at a later date regarding these projects. 
We also signed an incremental 400 megawatt DC model supply improvement with Strata Solar all of these volumes scheduled for delivery to Strata in 2017 and 2018. We have now signed agreements with Strata for over 1 gigawatt of volume, which signifies the growing importance of our relationship and also demonstrates the strength of demand for solar in the Southeastern United States. 
We are encouraged by these bookings with longer dated CODs and see this as an initial positive indication, particularly with respect to volumes. We still remain cautious on expectations regarding margins after 2016, given the limited visibility we have into the total business segment mix and the systems margins, given recent uncertainties and volatilities in respect to profit capital for solar projects. 
However, we continue to believe that the growing affordability of solar, which is enabled by our cost road map, is an attractive value proposition for utilities. We also believe that characteristics of utilities still solar plants as long-term contracted assets with no commodity price risk will increasingly represent a compelling investment opportunity for a wide variety of investors and continue to drive low cost of capital for the industry. 
Looking at the remaining portion of the 1.7 gigawatts of new bookings since last call, approximately 650 megawatts are for projects for CODs during 2016. With the addition of these projects, we have nearly 2 gigawatts of 2016 volume fully contracted. When taking into account significant number of mid-to late-stage opportunities, on a probability-weighted basis, all of our supply is fully allocated for 2016. 
The 650 megawatts of bookings are for projects that are primarily in the United States but had a diverse geographical dispersion. In Texas, we have signed a 119 megawatts 8 CPPA with Austin Energy. This is encouraging progress in a state with excellent solar resources and significant growth potential. Additionally, this is our first major domestic PPA award outside the Western United States and is evidence of the high priority we are placing on development activities in the South and Eastern portions of the country. 
With a number of other potential bookings opportunities that we continue to pursue, we expect more success in this region in the future. 
Going further east from Texas, we are continuing to see even more success across the South and Southeast. Under a nearly 200 megawatts DC module plus agreement with Silicone Range, we will be supplying projects across stats, such as Georgia, Mississippi and Tennessee. 
In Florida, we will be supplying 163 megawatts DC of modules to for 3 projects that will each utilize land leased from the military. These new bookings, in addition to the volume we have contracted with Strata, is growing evidence that customers recognize the strength of First Solar module technology in hot and specially humid environments. 
As we highlighted on last quarter's call, at the end of 2015, we expect to have a total energy density advantage as compared to multicrystalline silicon of around 5% in parts of the South and Southeast. This synergy density advantage represents a real increase in solar power plants output, which in turn, translates to greater value to our customers. 
Also highlighting the increasing interest in solar across the United States is the signing of EPC agreements to construct 3 projects in Indiana with American Electric Power. While the combined volume of these sites is smaller relative to other bookings in the quarter, it is significant in that we are seeing utilities demand for solar continuing to spread across new regions of the country. It also marks the beginning of a new relationship with another leading utility. 
Earlier this month, we announced the supply agreement with Clean Energy Selected to provide modules and other equipment to 4 projects in Colorado and Texas. Combined together, these projects introduce the concept of committee solar to nearly 1 million new potential residential users. 
Last December, we entered into a strategic partnership with CEC, and this is a further step in our ongoing relationship. With a superior as compared to solar and in an offering that greatly expands the potential for residential or business users to access solar power, in collaboration with their electric utility, we remain extremely optimistic about the long-term potential of Community Solar. 
Finally, international bookings this past quarter included third-party modules, fly agreements in India, Vietnam, Turkey and Malaysia. Moving onto Slide 6. Our bookings in terms of expected revenue have increased to $7.4 billion. The revenue increase is due to the strong bookings for the year partially offset by a higher mix of module and module plus deals in the new bookings as compared to the year-to-date revenue, which has a higher systems project mix. 
Turning to Slide 7, I will now cover our potential bookings opportunities, which have further increased to 17.4 gigawatts DC, an increase of approximately 700 megawatts from the prior quarter. The increase in potential bookings is especially in process in light of a couple of factors. 
First, our bookings opportunities were reduced by the  1.7 gigawatts of projects contracted. Second, we removed projects from the potential bookings list that we will not be able to contract due to supply constraints in 2016. The fact that our bookings opportunities is still increased despite these other items is a testament to the intense effort of our global sales team. 
Continuing on, our mid- to late stage bookings now stand at 3.9 gigawatts DC, an increase of 900 megawatts and a record number of advance stage opportunities. International bookings now make up over 85% of the potential mid-to late-stage bookings. 
Moving on to Slide 8, our updated potential bookings opportunities by geography show a significant mix shift to international opportunity. The opportunity outside of North America are now 13 gigawatts or 75% of the total. The largest growth of bookings opportunities since the prior quarter were in India and Latin America. Lastly, as we mentioned on our last call, we are planning to hold our next Analyst Day in 2016. We expect that timing to be in the first quarter of next year, following our Q4 earnings release. The specific date and webcast availability of the event will be shared at a later date. 
Now I'll turn it over to Mark who will provide detail on our preliminary third quarter financial results and discuss updated guidance for 2015.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Let me first address why we issued preliminary Q3 results today. As Jim indicated, there is a discrete income tax matter related to a holding company we have in a foreign jurisdiction. This item has recently com
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Let me first address why we issued preliminary Q3 results today. As Jim indicated, there is a discrete income tax matter related to a holding company we have in a foreign jurisdiction. This item has recently come to our attention, and we are working to complete our assessment as quickly as possible. It's important to note, this is not subject of inactive audit or controversy with authorities. Rather, this is an internal evaluation of required mainly administrative compliance. Based on our preliminary analysis, the tax matter could have an adverse impact of up to $40 million. This issue is discrete, and doesn't have an impact on our ongoing operations. 
Finally, it is important to highlight that this matter does not affect any of our foreign tax holidays in place. We anticipate releasing complete financial results and filing our Form 10-Q on or prior to the filing deadline of November 9. 
Now turning to Slide 10. I'll discuss our third quarter operational performance. Production in the quarter was 654 megawatts DC, an increase of 15% from the prior quarter, due to higher module efficiency, increased manufacturing capacity and less downtime for technology upgrades. Production was 46% higher year-over-year, due to the restart of manufacturing lines, higher efficiency in the addition of new capacity. Our capacity utilization increased by 9 percentage points from the second quarter to 94%, due to lower upgrade activity across the fleet. Our best line average efficiency was 16.4% during the quarter, an increase of 20 basis points from the prior quarter and 210 basis points year-over-year. 
Going forward, our lead line efficiency will remain essentially at this level until the next scheduled technology upgrades are rolled out after the first half of 2016. 
Our third quarter average module efficiency for the entire fleet was 15.8%, an increase of 40 basis points quarter-over-quarter and 160 basis points higher year-over-year. 
Second quarter end -- since quarter end, we have made good progress rolling out the efficiency improvements across our production line, and currently, the fleet average efficiency is 16.1%. I'll now turn to slide 11 to discuss their primarily P&L. We have record quarterly net sales in the third quarter of $1.27 billion, an increase of $375 million from the prior quarter. The increase in sales resulted primarily from the sale of majority interest in the partially constructed Desert Stateline project to Southern. This is the first quarter we have recognized revenue on Desert, and all revenues since the project inception was recognized in Q2. Essentially, approximately 45% of the total project revenue was recognized in Q3. Going forward, revenue recognition will continue on a percentage of completion basis, and our results will reflect the specific quarterly project activity until COD, which anticipated to be Q3 of 2016. 
Revenue was off to a higher across multiple other systems projects and third-party module sales. As a percent of total sales, our solar power systems revenue, which includes both our EPC revenue and solar modules use and systems projects, was 95%, a decrease of 3 percentage points from the prior quarter. 
Module plus sales, which also include our solar power systems, revenue totaled approximately $130 million in Q3, approximately 30% higher quarter-over-quarter. The increase in third-party module sales was related to volume shipped to India and revenue recognized on module sales to projects in the U.K. 
Gross margin for the quarter was 38.1% compared to 18.4% in the second quarter. The significantly higher gross margin percentage resulted from a sale of majority interest in Desert Stateline, improvements in system project costs and a $70 million benefit from a decrease in our module collection recycling obligation. 
Since the inception of the module end-of-life program, we have continued to pursue engineering and process improvements to reduce the cost of collecting and recycling the molecules. Our continuous improvement efforts have resulted in an automated and continuous flow process, which has significantly lowered the cost of the end-of-life program. 
In Q3, we completed a cost study for our module collection recycling program and determined the estimated future EOL obligation should be reduced based on our new continuous flow cycling process. While the reduction of the current -- in the current period, primarily related to module shifting in prior fiscal years, the improved process represent a significant cost savings that benefit both for solar and shareholders. 
Additionally, in the third quarter, we achieved significant reduction in our fleet average module cost per watt. While we no longer provide specific module cost per watt information, the impact of continued efficiency and throughput improvements are resulting in a substantial benefit. This can be seen in our Q3 component segment gross margins of 22%, excluding the impact of the EOL change. 
Third quarter operating expenses, including plant start ups, decreased by $20 million from Q2 to $87 million. In addition to benefiting cost of goods sold, the reduction of our EOL obligation previously discussed benefited Q3 operating expenses by $10 million. In addition, start up expenses decreased associated with the TetraSun production ramp. Lastly, G&A expenses were also lower versus prior quarter. 
The third quarter operating profit was $398 million compared to operating profit of $57 million in Q2. The improvement was driven by higher revenue, improved gross margin and lower operating expenses. The preliminary tax rate for the quarter was 13%. We have preliminary quarterly earnings of $3.38 per fully diluted share, on net income of $346 million. This compares to earnings of $0.93 per share in the prior quarter. 
Moving onto Slide 12, I'll now discuss the selected balance sheet items and cash flow summary. Cash and marketable securities increased slightly by $34 million and remained at $1.8 billion. Our net cash position was unchanged at $1.5 billion. The increase in cash during the quarter resulted from the sale of majority interest in Desert Stateline, partially offset by cash used for the ongoing contraction of the projects that are being built on balance sheet. 
Note, on balance sheet, we are currently constructing 1.2 gigawatts AC of projects, which will achieve commercial operation over the next 5 quarters. 
Our net working capital, including the change in noncurrent project assets and excluding cash and marketable securities, increased by $55 million from the prior quarter. The increase was attributed to the increase in trade and unbilled accounts receivables, partially offset by reductions in inventory and payables. 
Total debt decreased from the prior quarter by $14 million to $286 million, primarily due to the scheduled payments on our Malaysian loan, partially offset by an increase in debt of $16 million. Cash flow from operations was $21 million compared to cash flow used in operations of $17 million in the quarter. Free cash flow was a negative $17 million compared to negative free cash flow of $47 million in Q2. Capital expenditures were $45 million, an increase of $6 million from the prior quarter. Depreciation for the quarter was $61 million or $2 million lower than the prior quarter. 
Turning to Slide 13, I will now discuss our updated and preliminary full year 2015 guidance. The following guidance is preliminary, pending the determination and financial impacts of the tax that I discussed previously. First, we have left our net sales range of $3.5 billion to $3.6 billion unchanged. We continue to expect our systems revenue, which includes both EPC and solar modules used in systems projects, to be in the range of 90% to 95% of total revenue for the year. We are raising gross margin guidance 300 basis points to a revised range of 24% to 10 25%. This is a result of the favorable cost improvements achieved in Q3, as well as the benefit from the decrease in our obligations. Operating expenses, including plant start up, have been lowered by $20 million, the revised range of $395 million to $405 million. 
In addition to the $10 million reduction from the decreased in the obligations, we are lowering operating expense guidance to reflect lower R&D testing costs and greater cost control focus. in our projected effective tax rate have increased to a range of 4% to 6%, reflecting our latest view of income mix. 
Note that this rate incorporates on a full year basis of a $28 million net tax benefit associated with the payables ruling from a foreign tax authority. As discussed on our last call, the benefit of favorable ruling in Q2 was $42 million. However, on a full year basis, the benefit it is now $28 million, due to the decrease in our EU obligation recognized in Q3. 
Preliminary earnings per share guidance at the midpoint has increased by nearly $1 per share to a revised range of $4.30 to $4.50 for fully diluted share. The increased earnings guidance reflects the $57 million benefit net of tax power lawyer obligation, balance of the higher guidance is from operational improvements realized in Q3 results and included in our Q4 forecast. 
Capital expenditure guidance is unchanged at $175 million to $200 million. The guidance range for our net ending cash and changing working capital have changed slightly as we have narrowed the previously range provided. Shipping guidance is unchanged from our prior expectation. Lastly, consistent with prior indications, our guidance for the remainder of the year does not anticipate any drop-down of assets into 8.3. 
Looking forward to 2016, we are planning to host a mid-December call to provide guidance for the 2016 calendar year. Given the level of visibility we have in 2016 at this point, we fell this would be an appropriate time to share our outlook with the investment community. The date and specific details of the call will be made available in the coming weeks. 
Turning to the next slide, I'll summarize our progress during the past quarter. First, we delivered outstanding financial results for the quarter, with sales of $1.3 billion, gross margin of over 38% and preliminary earnings of $3.38 per share. We have raised our full year preliminary guidance range to $4.30 to $4.50 on the strength of our Q3 earnings and ongoing operational improvements. Our technology continues to improve rapidly, with the Q3 fleet average efficiency of 15.8% and best line of lined 16.4%. Our pipeline continues to grow with record year-to-date bookings of 3.1 gigawatts. And the book-to-bill ratio for the year will be greater than 1:1. Potential bookings is of 17.4 gigawatts is going approximately 700 megawatts even as we reported record bookings. Our mid-to late-stage opportunities are also the strongest they've ever been with 3.9 gigawatts of project. With this, we conclude our prepared remarks and open up the call for questions. Operator?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Vishal Shah with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Vishal Shah with Deutsche Bank.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great progress in the bookings and the cost front. Can you guys talked about 1-plus gigawatts of bookings beyond 2016? Can you just talk a little bit about how you think the margins in the backlog would look like beyond 2016? Can you give in the efficienc
componenttext: Great progress in the bookings and the cost front. Can you guys talked about 1-plus gigawatts of bookings beyond 2016? Can you just talk a little bit about how you think the margins in the backlog would look like beyond 2016? Can you give in the efficiency improvement, can you maintain 15-plus-percent margins in the systems business beyond 2016 and up?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vishal, I think I made the comment that while we're doing increasing confidence with respect to volumes, I think it's a little early for us to have a firm view on margins. And primarily because with respect to the systems business, that's going to be
componenttext: Yes, Vishal, I think I made the comment that while we're doing increasing confidence with respect to volumes, I think it's a little early for us to have a firm view on margins. And primarily because with respect to the systems business, that's going to be dependent upon ultimate realization of those projects, which is going to depend upon the relevant discount rates and/or cost of capital. And with the dislocation we've seen in markets recently, I think my frank view is that sort of through the end of this year, there's going to be a degree of uncertainty on that so I don't think we would want to comment. I think as we move into 2016, capital markets should come down and we should begin to get some visibility on where those are going to end up and that will give us with a better visibility into the margins on the systems business.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would say, Vishal, is that a portion of business on the systems side, those are projects that are towards the latter part of this decade, which we've demonstrated with our past that when we are able to get control of assets with long dat
componenttext: The other thing I would say, Vishal, is that a portion of business on the systems side, those are projects that are towards the latter part of this decade, which we've demonstrated with our past that when we are able to get control of assets with long dated contracted period like that of PPAs that are open to the horizon that we've been able to accrete a significant value of that horizon as it relates to benefits that we seen, the knowledge and other assets that we've made so we feel confident with the long term margin capture that we'll capture on those assets, it's just a matter of communicated, understanding how cost of capital evolves and how things in the market evolve over the next year or so will probably create a better picture for how we realize margin on those assets further out into the decade.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ben Kallo with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Kallo with Robert W. Baird.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. First, on the YieldCo front, how are you guys viewing the YieldCo at its current price? What can you do to support it? Second, some people will say Stateline helped you on this quarter and the cost cutting is done. Can you just talk a
componenttext: Couple of questions. First, on the YieldCo front, how are you guys viewing the YieldCo at its current price? What can you do to support it? Second, some people will say Stateline helped you on this quarter and the cost cutting is done. Can you just talk about what you can do to expand margin going forward? I'll leave it there.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This market will take a question and I'll let Jim to take the Stateline question. From a YieldCo standpoint, as we said on the 8.3 call a month or so ago, both sponsors at this point in time are committed to drop downs that we would envision in the first
componenttext: This market will take a question and I'll let Jim to take the Stateline question. From a YieldCo standpoint, as we said on the 8.3 call a month or so ago, both sponsors at this point in time are committed to drop downs that we would envision in the first half of '16. We've also indicated that we did not have any choice capital at this point in time. We've left that in our capacity in 8.3 to manage those anticipated drop downs with the revolver, the late the term loan plus the efficiencies that we have embedded in the term structure. So what I would say, we're still moving forward and we believe we will be able to drop-down those assets to the right value equation to the sponsors and create accretions to 8.3. We'll continue to evaluate how the equity trades over time and will continue to assess how would structure assets beyond the first half of '16 the grass we said before, we made the to put leverage on these assets, which would then allow us to create a leverage yield to the 8.3 shareholder that is accretive. so there's other structuring options that we do have, that we're continuing to look at. But beyond the first half of '16, we would say we're committed to the drop downs, we'll continue to evaluate the market and ensure that the drop downs makes sense in the latter half of '16.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And on the other clearly, we benefited from a project that's been part of the portfolio for a long time and everybody's known about the operational performance this quarter clearly extends well beyond that. That clearly has no impact upon the booking
componenttext: Yes. And on the other clearly, we benefited from a project that's been part of the portfolio for a long time and everybody's known about the operational performance this quarter clearly extends well beyond that. That clearly has no impact upon the bookings side of the equation, which was the strongest quarter in our history from that standpoint. In terms of can we continue to drive margin and competitiveness through cost reductions. As I have stated regularly, that the religion around here and we have a cost road map that will remain committed to, that extends well beyond where we are today. We've never backed away from that roadmap and we've continued to hit the road map that we laid out several years ago. Further, we continue to spend robustly on R&D, and we continue to build opportunities that will allow us that roadmap to extend beyond the commitments that we have today, particularly outside of the module and into the balance of system. And then at the corporate level, we continue to have a focus on growing the business while at the same time, getting leaner. And so, let's see our OpEx come down not only on a unit basis but also on an aggregate basis. And so, given how radically we've changed the business, the fact that we've maintained cost control from an OpEx standpoint, I think is a notable accomplishment for the organization. So there's no doubt on our part that we have the ability to continue to drive competitiveness and not in some narrow fashion, but broadly across the entire business, being very reflective of the decision to be vertically integrated and to give us the ability to target all aspects of the value chain.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would say is that if you look at it with the guidance up as we indicated by about $1.35 or so, none of that $0.35 had anything to do with Stateline. So if you want to look at this we've always said there's been lumpiness about the timing
componenttext: The other thing I would say is that if you look at it with the guidance up as we indicated by about $1.35 or so, none of that $0.35 had anything to do with Stateline. So if you want to look at this we've always said there's been lumpiness about the timing of revenue recognition in the systems business, and particularly, if we look at it strength in the quarter is supported by Stateline. But as it relates to the upside to the year, the operational benefit is not reflective of Stateline.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttextpreview: I'll have 2 questions the first one relates to the business you're starting to see in southeast, and particularly, U.S. projects that you might be seeing post 2016. What's driving it? Is it state-level ricks? Is it renewable portfolio standards? Is it fee
componenttext: I'll have 2 questions the first one relates to the business you're starting to see in southeast, and particularly, U.S. projects that you might be seeing post 2016. What's driving it? Is it state-level ricks? Is it renewable portfolio standards? Is it feel replacement? Is it some competition on the about? And then the other question is you're obviously taking a break on the upgrading the capacity because you're fully deployed. Does this also mean that we see a sort of break in the progress in terms of energy efficiency? Will you at the end of the height as come back improvement in line efficiency at that point?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll tackle the first, the South East. I think there's a broad set that reasons. It has less to do with and more to do with cost structures getting down to a point where they represent a compelling value within the energy mix in that part of the country.
componenttext: I'll tackle the first, the South East. I think there's a broad set that reasons. It has less to do with and more to do with cost structures getting down to a point where they represent a compelling value within the energy mix in that part of the country. As I have consistently said, there's a broad awakening on the part of utilities to the value that solar represents, and in particular, as they look forward to the clean power plant, as they look forward to constraints on the ability to operate existing coal plants or constructs new coal plants, they see an increase in shift towards natural gas, and accordingly, a significant exposure to natural gas commodities. And while natural gas is really very, very inexpensive today, everybody remains cautious and worried about future increases in that commodity. So it's broadly the ability to diversify their generation mix into a technology that is cost effective and affordable in the context of today's prices and also offers a significant hedge against future commodity prices. I think that it's that broad package of characteristics that is really what is compelling people to procure utilities, in particular, to include portable generation mix. Your other question.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is on the efficiency.
componenttext: Is on the efficiency.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the efficiency. So there won't be a step function because when we begin applying -- we will continue to be working, we're continuously working from an R&D standpoint. So when it comes to implementation of each new advance, you can't initiate it across
componenttext: On the efficiency. So there won't be a step function because when we begin applying -- we will continue to be working, we're continuously working from an R&D standpoint. So when it comes to implementation of each new advance, you can't initiate it across the entire fleet at the same time and you also -- we are also very cautious about implementing too many advances in a single moment because you have a great deal of difficulty -- it's more challenging to track and determined that it is performing at production scale exactly the way you anticipate it and to make sure that from a quality standpoint, you're delivering what you promised. So there's a risk management aspect to how many new advantage you throw into each iteration of the product. So you will see, it go from flat, to back, to a relatively steep curve in terms of the advances, but I wouldn't describe it as a step function.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Krish Sankar from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Krish Sankar from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Good job on execution and numbers for the quarter. I'm just wondering, the focus to go more international, is it part of the reason because the development in landscape has cooled off a bit in the U.S? And if so, or if so, what are the prim
componenttext: Two questions. Good job on execution and numbers for the quarter. I'm just wondering, the focus to go more international, is it part of the reason because the development in landscape has cooled off a bit in the U.S? And if so, or if so, what are the primary reason and whatever returns or margins do you expect on these international projects?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The reason for going international is that the last 2.5 decades understanding the power industry have taught me to the power industry tends to be cyclical on a regional basis. Often times, those cycles tend to be non-correlated. And if you want to build a
componenttext: The reason for going international is that the last 2.5 decades understanding the power industry have taught me to the power industry tends to be cyclical on a regional basis. Often times, those cycles tend to be non-correlated. And if you want to build a smooth, steadier business profile, needed to participate in multiple geographies, multiple economies so that you have the ability to ship to whatever happens to be the area of greatest need. It's less about the U.S. and more about the desire to grow, the desire to diversify to markets in which we can play. It also speaks to the fact that as our products has improved, as our efficiency has improved, as our spectral response has improved, we're just is increasingly competitive across the broader set of geographies and that makes it possible for us to go out and compete in these geographies. So it's not one single discrete reason, it's part of a broader strategy to build what we believe will be a robust growing and steady business in the future.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the other one question you had on the returns, I'd look at it at the portfolio. So in every region, every market has its own unique I'll call it larger margin solar in general turns to words computing terms of alternative sources strategy. On the
componenttext: I think the other one question you had on the returns, I'd look at it at the portfolio. So in every region, every market has its own unique I'll call it larger margin solar in general turns to words computing terms of alternative sources strategy. On the dynamics on how competitive our technology may be in specific markets, given high climate conditions, given humidity, given spectral response, given you look at it from a portfolio standpoint and you'll find in some markets, the returns that we would see our multiple, higher than what we would see here in the U.S. some markets there may be lower than what we would see in the U.S. but on average, I would say that we're finding very robust returns and that our comfortable and generally could be stronger than the U.S., again you have to look at it on a market by market basis though.

The other $0.35 is just through operational performance. about $0.20 or so from, $0.25 shipped up in cost of goods sold as we're seeing continued improvements around cost a lot. Our engineering EPC business in our overall ability to drive cost out of our balances system is improving better than we have anticipated. And then as Jim indicated, we are increasingly focused on managing our operating expenses. So we brought that down by about another $0.10 or so. So it's a combination of good performance on manufacturing and managing our operating expenses.

componenttextpreview: First, what's asked in terms of commercial and industrial markets were and are you seeing there and what of the prospect there for you guys in '16 and '17? And second, in terms of your cost road map toward $1 a watt, what are the biggest liver sphere beyo
componenttext: First, what's asked in terms of commercial and industrial markets were and are you seeing there and what of the prospect there for you guys in '16 and '17? And second, in terms of your cost road map toward $1 a watt, what are the biggest liver sphere beyond the module cost reductions?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: first, on the commercial and industrial front, we do have some customers that are integrators and developers that will use our modules on commercial and industrial not a gigantic purpose but they are some volumes. I think on ground commercial and industri
componenttext: first, on the commercial and industrial front, we do have some customers that are integrators and developers that will use our modules on commercial and industrial not a gigantic purpose but they are some volumes. I think on ground commercial and industrial, we see a robust set of opportunity. It's very hard for us to differentiate in the sales chain with a lot of our developers between utility, the repurchases and purchases that are bilateral to commercial and industrial customers. Wrote that exactly the same to us, there's not a big extension, but we know there is a fair bit of it out there in the contracts that have been booked and signed recently. In terms of what levers did we pull other than the module. It's the balance of system and it's all aspects of the balance of system, from structures to materials, to material costs, to the means and methods of construction. There are -- when you look across labor and materials, they are both significant contributors to the balance of system costs and we are spending a lot of time and effort on reducing labor, not just in terms of labor rates but actual changing the means and methods of construction to reduce the number of actions and amount of time it takes to install and reducing materials on the rest of the balance of systems. So it's all about the balance of system when you get past the module.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the other thing to point out in that regard is also the balance of system is synergistic to the module. So as we drive up the efficiency of the module, effectively, it reduces the variable balance of system that is needed to install every megawatt
componenttext: I think the other thing to point out in that regard is also the balance of system is synergistic to the module. So as we drive up the efficiency of the module, effectively, it reduces the variable balance of system that is needed to install every megawatt of energy that we put into the system. So you can look at it in isolation as we continue to drive efficiency naturally drive down the balance of system cost. And that will help us move towards the cost road map that we laid out.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, clearly there's a number of YieldCo that indicated that at this point in time, they don't anticipate being aggressive or acquisitive in looking for projects. In some case, they've indicated in the next year, it could be longer. But we have, histor
componenttext: I mean, clearly there's a number of YieldCo that indicated that at this point in time, they don't anticipate being aggressive or acquisitive in looking for projects. In some case, they've indicated in the next year, it could be longer. But we have, historically, not sold to YieldCos or traditional tax equity structures. We've chosen to partner with strategic with tax capacity. So I would say that one of the market is still very robust, as you can see with our ability to sell down Stateline into with Southern. Now what that means now is that more and more people will be looking to try to engage with the Dominion, the Berkshire, you can go down the line because they may be the most active buyers in the market. And what position of strength that we're in is that we have very strong relationships with a number of those parties. They obviously love the First Solar brand, they love the First Solar relationships, they love the comfort. And so I'm sure that there will be some impact in the market. We think we're in a fortunate position because we have very strong relationship with a number of those parties. But the other thing I would say is that these assets are very attractive. I mean, there's a number of parties that want to have solar assets, long-dated contracted assets with investment-grade counterparties, and the ability to acquire will come to market in '16 what could be in the market in '17 and '18 is there's a window that's may be closing in terms of the number of projects that can be acquired. And I would expect at least  a lot of our traditional buyers capacity will be very aggressive throughout 2016.

componenttext: First quick question is think about international mixer, can you comment about the module versus the projects, particularly in the new geographies? How you think about the incremental margin on those year basis. Right now and kind of got that a bit before but are you thinking about these? Have you added the contracts as being true development opportunities or for the most part, should we be thinking about specially India has more of a module or module plus kind of opportunity? And then perhaps as a second unrelated question I'll throw it out there now, the activity, et cetera, how much of that is EPP driven and how much of it is overhang in the early action credit being all the way out in 2020 limiting procurement, just wanted to get your thoughts on that.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's step back to development and international side pictures of each, we look at each market discreetly. One of the learning server the last several years is you cannot generalize about even within the same region, even neighboring countries, often t
componenttext: So let's step back to development and international side pictures of each, we look at each market discreetly. One of the learning server the last several years is you cannot generalize about even within the same region, even neighboring countries, often times you can't generalize about what the basis makes for us is going to look like. So the way we think about development is, if we do development, we want to get paid for it. And when we say that what that means is we want to earn a return, that's above and beyond what we believe the margin or module plus type of would be if we're going to engage in the development process. And narrow markets where we go and we see the opportunity to get paid for being the developer. And there are markets where we absolutely do not see that opportunity. So when you look across the world, Japan is a market where we have felt that we can get paid for being the developer and we are very active in the development. India is a market where we feel we can get paid for being the developer and we are at this as a developer. What's difference is there are capital constraints in India that don't exist in other markets that limits how much development we're going to be able to do so we also are very aggressive on the module and module plus front in India. As we look at new and different markets around the world, there is an initial process that it takes us a little while to get on the ground and spend enough time in the markets to really whether this entitlement is going to just about development. I think it's fair to say that at this point, our method of operation is with the module. And then, as we began establish the market share, get some resource on the ground and get it market, we'll look hard at whether this is development opportunity. But I don't think you can generalize -- I don't think you could say all of the incremental demand internationally is going to be module only. That's certainly not a pretty thing about. But also think it's safe to say, it's not all going to be development. Development is OpEx and it is always complicated in a new market. And so can only take on some many new markets at a time without driving our OpEx to unacceptable levels. And so, it's going to be a balance between let's take the OpEx resources that we chose to live within and let's apply those in the markets we're going to development standpoint. And then, let's go with a lesser in other markets where we can capture market share on an OpEx like basis, admittedly, at probably lower margins but still accretive to the overall outcome for the company.

componenttext: Business act on form right. My question is that gas prices and the trend that we've seen in recent months. We think there's a believe that PPA prices might go up in '17 with the ATC but what is lower gas do to that?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quite frankly, the front month of natural gas doesn't really enter into the discussion. All of our conversation in the U.S. are 25, between 15- and 30-year PPAs. So the utilities are looking at in their energy resource planning on their long-term curves.
componenttext: Quite frankly, the front month of natural gas doesn't really enter into the discussion. All of our conversation in the U.S. are 25, between 15- and 30-year PPAs. So the utilities are looking at in their energy resource planning on their long-term curves. And I don't think their longer term analysis has changed. If you assume that these low prices are going to pull rig count down, when you look at the production cost and stack up the bases against that production costs, I think everybody gets to the same kind of level when you get out 5 to 10 years, and that is the point on the curve that is more impactful. If you got to a position in the United States where people believe that $2.50 gas prices were going to be the norm for the next 15 years, I think that might change the discussion. But I don't think that's what people have in their mind at this point.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way we restructured Stateline is very structured so the other assets sold the majority interest. So the structure is the same. Again, the tax asset will be monetized. 51% of the cash flows go with the majority owner and then the 49% of the cash flows
componenttext: The way we restructured Stateline is very structured so the other assets sold the majority interest. So the structure is the same. Again, the tax asset will be monetized. 51% of the cash flows go with the majority owner and then the 49% of the cash flows would come to First Solar, and again, that's over the horizon after the flip horizontal that the tax and the cash are split the same way. At this point in time, we've -- Stateline is a asset for 8.3 and anticipate to achieve COD for Stateline in Q3 of '16. We'll continue to evaluate the market assuming that the market economics makes sense, and that would be the incentive. What we would do is we would drop Stateline at 8.3.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its preliminary financial results for the third quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its preliminary financial results for the third quarter of 2015. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. With me today are Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Widmar, Chief Financial Officer. Jim will provide a business and technology update. Then Mark will discuss our third quarter preliminary financial results and provide updated guidance for 2015. We will then open up the call for questions.
Most of the financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Please note, this call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statements contained in the press release and the slides published today for a more complete description. It is now my pleasure to introduce Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer. Jim?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. As indicated in our press release, we have issued preliminary financial results for the third quarter while we complete an analysis of the discrete income tax matter related to a foreign t
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. As indicated in our press release, we have issued preliminary financial results for the third quarter while we complete an analysis of the discrete income tax matter related to a foreign tax jurisdiction. While Mark will discuss this matter in more detail later, I wish to emphasize that this matter does not have any adverse impact on the ongoing operations of the company. We are working towards a full and timely resolution of the issue. Now let me turn to an update on the business and the outstanding performance of this past quarter. 
In the third quarter, we had tremendous execution across all parts of the organization, which has resulted in strong results from a financial bookings and technology standpoint. Before further discussing these points, it is worth taking a moment to reflect on the progress we have made as a company over the past several years. 
In 2012, First Solar and the entire solar industry faced a period of disruption, resulting from declines in unsustainable subsidized solar markets. At our Q1 2012 earnings call, we laid out a 5-year plan and identify key 2016 financial targets to focus the organization and create value for our shareholders. As we near the end of year 4 of this plan, with year-to-date bookings of 3.1 gigawatts, earnings guidance of over $4 per share and the strongest technology position in our company's history, it warrants recognizing the tremendous progress that has been made towards these objectives since 2012. 
With the vision 2020 plan that we introduced last quarter, we will continue this pattern of setting challenging goals and working to achieve them. 
Turning to our technology performance in the third quarter. Our fleet average efficiency improved to 15.8%, a 40-basis-point improvement from the second quarter. Our lead line efficiency averaged 16.4%, a 20-basis-point improvement quarter-over-quarter and a 210-basis-point improvement versus Q3 2014. A more modest improvement in the sequential lead line efficiency relative to prior quarters is a reflection of an intentional and temporary pole of the new technology implementations. As we have stated previously, we are completing the rollout of our technology upgrades across the entire fleet this year. 
In the first half of 2016, we will prioritize full production utilization in order to meet strong demands and then resume the implementation of new module efficiency programs thereafter. 
Next, we are very pleased with our progress in securing new business for the future. Slide 5 highlights our year-to-date bookings, which now stand at 3.1 gigawatts. With 2 months left in the year, we have already set a new annual bookings records and anticipate adding to this total before the end of the year. With at least 3.1 gigawatts of bookings for the year and projected full year shipments of approximately 2.9 gigawatts, we will once again exceed our goal of a 1:1 book-to-bill ratio. 
Our total 1.7 gigawatts of bookings since last earnings call are not only impressive in size, but also reflects some positive indications of utility scale solar demand in the U.S. after 2016. Approximately 60% or over 1 gigawatt DC of the total 1.7 gigawatt DC growth to our projects in the U.S. that has commercial operation dates after 2016. Approximately 630 megawatts DC of this volume represent PPAs that have been signed with a leading utility in the Western United States and span across 4 projects, which are anticipated to commence delivering power into the utilities here in late 2019. 
As with other PPA awards, these projects are subject to final utility commission approval. More details will be made public at a later date regarding these projects. 
We also signed an incremental 400 megawatt DC module supply agreement with Strata Solar. All of these volumes scheduled for delivery to Strata in 2017 and 2018. We have now signed agreements with Strata for over 1 gigawatt of volume, which signifies the growing importance of our relationship and also demonstrates the strength of demand for solar in the Southeastern United States. 
We are encouraged by these bookings with longer dated CODs and see this as an initial positive indication, particularly with respect to volumes. We still remain cautious on expectations regarding margins after 2016, given the limited visibility we have into the total business segment mix and the systems margins, given recent uncertainties and volatility in respect to profit capital for solar projects. 
However, we continue to believe that the growing affordability of solar, which is enabled by our cost road map, is an attractive value proposition for the utilities. We also believe that the characteristics of utilities still solar plants as long-term contracted assets with no commodity price risk will increasingly represent a compelling investment opportunity for a wide variety of investors and continue to drive low cost of capital for the industry. 
Looking at the remaining portion of the 1.7 gigawatts of new bookings since last call, approximately 650 megawatts are for projects for CODs during 2016. With the addition of these projects, we have nearly 2 gigawatts of 2016 volume fully contracted. When taking into account the significant number of mid- to late-stage opportunities, on a probability-weighted basis, all of our supply is fully allocated for 2016. 
The 650 megawatts of bookings are for projects that are primarily in the United States, but had a diverse geographical dispersion. In Texas, we have signed in a 119 megawatts AC PPA with Austin Energy. This is encouraging progress in a state with excellent solar resources and significant growth potential. Additionally, this is our first major domestic PPA award outside the Western United States and is evidence of the high priority we are placing on development activities in the South and Eastern portions of the country. 
With a number of other potential bookings opportunities that we continue to pursue, we expect more success in this region in the future.
Going further east from Texas, we are continuing to see even more success across the South and Southeast. Under a nearly 200 megawatts DC module plus agreement with Silicon Ranch, we will be supplying projects across states such as Georgia, Mississippi and Tennessee. 
In Florida, we will be supplying 163 megawatts DC of modules to [indiscernible] for 3 projects that will each utilize land leased from the military. These new bookings, in addition to the volume we have contracted with Strata, is growing evidence that customers recognize the strength of First Solar module technology in hot and especially humid environments. 
As we highlighted on last quarter's call, at the end of 2015, we expect having a total energy density advantage as compared to multicrystalline silicon of around 5% in parts of the South and Southeast. This synergy density advantage represents a real increase in solar power plants output, which, in turn, translates to greater value to our customers. 
Also highlighting the increasing interest in solar across the United States is our signing of EPC agreements to construct 3 projects in Indiana with American Electric Power. While this combined volume of these sites is smaller relative to other bookings in the quarter, it is significant in that we are seeing utilities demand for solar continuing to spread across new regions of the country. It also marks the beginning of a new relationship with another leading utility. 
Earlier this month, we announced the supply agreement with Clean Energy Collective to provide modules and other equipment to 4 projects in Colorado and Texas. Combined together, these projects introduce the concept of committee solar to nearly 1 million new potential residential users. 
Last December, we entered into a strategic partnership with CEC, and this is a further step in our ongoing relationship. With a superior cost structure as compared to RESOP solar and an offering may greatly expand the potential for residential or business users to access solar power, in collaboration with their electric utility. We remain extremely optimistic about the long-term potential of Community Solar. 
Finally, international bookings this past quarter included third-party modules, fly agreements in India, Vietnam, Turkey and Malaysia.
Moving onto Slide 6. Our bookings in terms of expected revenue have increased to $7.4 billion. The revenue increase is due to the strong bookings for the year, partially offset by a higher mix of Module and Modules Plus deals in the new bookings as compared to the year-to-date revenue, which has a higher systems project mix. 
Turning to Slide 7, I will now cover our potential bookings opportunities, which have further increased to 17.4 gigawatts DC, an increase of approximately 700 megawatts from the prior quarter. The increase in potential bookings is especially in process in light of a couple of factors. First, our bookings opportunities were reduced by the 1.7 gigawatts of projects contracted. Second, we removed projects from the potential bookings list that we will not be able to contract due to supply constraints in 2016. The fact that our bookings opportunities is still increased despite these other items is a testament to the intense effort by our global sales team. 
Continuing on, our mid- to late-stage bookings now stand at 3.9 gigawatts DC, an increase of 900 megawatts and a record number of advanced stage opportunities. International bookings now make up over 85% of the potential mid- to late-stage bookings. 
Moving on to Slide 8, our updated potential bookings opportunities by geography show a significant mix shift to international opportunities. The opportunities outside of North America are now 13 gigawatts or 75% of the total. The largest growth of bookings opportunities since the prior quarter were in India and Latin America. Lastly, as we mentioned on our last call, we are planning to hold our next Analyst Day in 2016. We expect that timing to be in the first quarter of next year, following our Q4 earnings release. The specific date and webcast availability of the event will be shared at a later date. 
Now I'll turn it over to Mark who will provide detail on our preliminary third quarter financial results and discuss updated guidance for 2015.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Let me first address why we issued preliminary Q3 results today. As Jim indicated, there is a discrete income tax matter related to a holding company we have in a foreign jurisdiction. This item has recently com
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Let me first address why we issued preliminary Q3 results today. As Jim indicated, there is a discrete income tax matter related to a holding company we have in a foreign jurisdiction. This item has recently come to our attention, and we are working to complete our assessment as quickly as possible. It's important to note, this item is not a subject of an active audit or controversy with tax authorities. Rather, this is an internal evaluation of required mainly administrative compliance. Based on our preliminary analysis, the tax matter could have an adverse impact of up to $40 million. This issue is discrete, and does not have an impact on our ongoing operations. 
Finally, it is important to highlight that this matter does not affect any of our foreign tax holidays in place. We anticipate releasing complete financial results and filing our Form 10-Q on or prior to the filing deadline of November 9. 
Now turning to Slide 10. I'll discuss our third quarter operational performance. Production in the quarter was 654 megawatts DC, an increase of 16% from the prior quarter, due to higher module efficiency, increased manufacturing capacity and less downtime for technology upgrades. Production was 46% higher year-over-year, due to the restart of manufacturing lines, higher efficiency and the addition of new capacity. Our factory capacity utilization increased by 9 percentage points from the second quarter to 94%, due to the lower upgrade activity across the fleet. Our best line average efficiency was 16.4% during the quarter, an increase of 20 basis points from the prior quarter and 210 basis points year-over-year. 
Going forward, our lead line efficiency will remain essentially at this level, until the next scheduled technology upgrades are rolled out after the first half of 2016. 
Our third quarter average module efficiency for the entire fleet was 15.8%, an increase of 40 basis points quarter-over-quarter and 160 basis points higher year-over-year. 
Second quarter end -- since quarter end, we have made good progress rolling out the efficiency improvements across our production line, and currently, the fleet average efficiency is 16.1%.
I'll now turn to slide 11 to discuss the preliminary P&L. We have record quarterly net sales in the third quarter of $1.27 billion, an increase of $375 million from the prior quarter. The increase in sales resulted primarily from the sale of majority interests in the partially constructed Desert Stateline project to Southern. This is the first quarter we have recognized revenue on Desert Stateline, and all revenues since the project inception was recognized in Q3. Potentially, approximately 45% of the total project revenue was recognized in Q3. Going forward, revenue recognition will continue on a percentage of completion basis, and our results will reflect a specific quarterly project activity until COD, which is anticipated to be Q3 of 2016. 
Revenue was also higher across multiple other systems projects and third-party module sales. As a percent of total sales, our solar power systems revenue, which includes both our EPC revenue and solar modules use and systems projects, was 95%, a decrease of 3 percentage points from the prior quarter. 
Module Plus sales, which also include our solar power systems, revenue totaled approximately $130 million in Q3, approximately 30% higher quarter-over-quarter. The increase in third-party module sales was related to volume shipped to India and revenue recognized on module sales to projects in the U.K. 
Gross margin for the quarter was 38.1%, compared to 18.4% in the second quarter. The significantly higher gross margin percentage resulted from a sale of majority interest in Desert Stateline, improvements in system project costs and a $70 million benefit from a decrease in our module collection recycling obligation. 
Since the inception of the module end-of-life program, we have continued to pursue engineering and process improvement to reduce the cost of collecting and recycling the modules. Our continuous improvement efforts have resulted in an automated and continuous flow process, which has significantly lowered the cost of the end-of-life program. 
In Q3, we completed a cost study for our module collection recycling program and determined the estimated future EOL obligation should be reduced based on our new continuous flow cycling process. While the reduction of the current -- in the current period, primarily related to module shift in prior fiscal years, the improved process represent significant cost savings that benefit both First Solar and its shareholders. 
Additionally, in the third quarter, we achieved significant reduction in our fleet average module cost per watt. While we no longer provide specific module cost per watt information, the impact of continued efficiency and throughput improvements are resulting in a substantial benefit. This can be seen in our Q3 component segment gross margin of 22%, excluding the impact of the EOL change. 
Third quarter operating expenses, including plant start-up, decreased by $20 million from Q2 to $87 million. In addition to benefiting cost of goods sold, the reduction in our EOL obligation previously discussed benefited Q3 operating expenses by $10 million. In addition, start-up expenses decreased associated with the TetraSun production ramp. Lastly, G&A expenses were also lower versus the prior quarter. 
The third quarter operating profit was $398 million compared to operating profit of $57 million in Q2. The improvement was driven by higher revenue, improved gross margin and lower operating expenses. The preliminary tax rate for the quarter was 13%. We had preliminary quarterly earnings of $3.38 per a fully diluted share, on net income of $346 million. This compares to earnings of $0.93 per share in the prior quarter. 
Moving onto Slide 12, I'll now discuss the selected balance sheet items and cash flow summary. Cash and marketable securities increased slightly by $34 million and remained at $1.8 billion. Our net cash position was unchanged at $1.5 billion. The increase in cash during the quarter resulted from the sale of majority interest in Desert Stateline, partially offset by cash used for the ongoing contraction of the projects that are being built on balance sheet. 
Note, on balance sheet, we are currently constructing 1.2 gigawatts AC of projects, which will achieve commercial operation over the next 5 quarters. 
Our net working capital, including the change in noncurrent project assets and excluding cash and marketable securities, increased by $55 million from the prior quarter. The increase was attributed to the increase in trade and unbilled accounts receivables, partially offset by reductions in inventories and payables. 
Total debt decreased from the prior quarter by $14 million to $286 million, primarily due to the scheduled payments on our Malaysian loan, partially offset by an increase [indiscernible] debt of $16 million. Cash flow from operations was $21 million compared to cash flow used in operations of $17 million in the quarter. Free cash flow was a negative $17 million compared to negative free cash flow of $47 million in Q2. Capital expenditures were $45 million, an increase of $6 million from the prior quarter. Free cash for the quarter was $61 million or $2 million lower than the prior quarter. 
Turning to Slide 13, I will now discuss our updated and preliminary full year 2015 guidance. The following guidance is preliminary, pending the determination and financial impacts of the tax that I discussed previously. First, we have left our net sales range of $3.5 billion to $3.6 billion unchanged. We continue to expect our systems revenue, which includes both EPC and solar modules used in systems projects, to be in the range of 90% to 95% of total revenue for the year. We are raising gross margin guidance 300 basis points to a revised range of 24% to 25%. This is a result of the favorable cost improvements achieved in Q3, as well as the benefit from the decrease in our EOL obligations. Operating expenses, including plant start-up, have been lowered by $20 million, the revised range of $395 million up to $405 million. 
In addition to the $10 million reduction from a decrease in EOL obligations, we are lowering operating expense guidance to reflect lower R&D testing costs and greater cost control focus. Our full year projected effective tax rate has increased to a range of 4% to 6%, reflecting our latest view of jurisdictional income mix. 
Note that this rate incorporates on a full year basis, a $28 million net tax benefit associated with the payables ruling from a foreign tax authority. As discussed on our last call, the benefit of favorable ruling in Q2 was $42 million. However, on a full year basis, the benefit it is now estimated to be $28 million, due to the decrease in our EOL obligation recognized in Q3. 
Preliminary earnings per share guidance at the midpoint has increased by nearly $1 per share to a revised range of $4.30 to $4.50 for fully diluted share. The increased earnings guidance reflects the $0.60 benefit, net of tax from our lower EOL obligation. Balance of the higher guidance is from operational improvements realized in Q3 results and included in our Q4 forecast. 
Capital expenditure guidance is unchanged at $175 million to $200 million. The guidance range for our net ending cash and changing working capital have changed slightly as we have narrowed the previously range provided. Shipping guidance is unchanged from our prior expectation. Lastly, consistent with prior indications, our guidance for the remainder of the year does not anticipate any drop-down of assets into 8.3. 
Looking forward to 2016, we are planning to host a mid-December call to provide guidance for the 2016 calendar year. Given the level of visibility we have in 2016 at this point, we feel that this would be an appropriate time to share our outlook with the investment community. The date and specific details of the call will be made available in the coming weeks. 
Turning to the next slide, I'll summarize our progress during the past quarter. First, we delivered outstanding financial results for the quarter, with sales of $1.3 billion, gross margin of over 38% and preliminary earnings of $3.38 per share. We have raised our full year preliminary guidance range to $4.30 to $4.50 on the strength of our Q3 earnings and ongoing operational improvements. Our technology continues to improve rapidly, with the Q3 fleet average efficiency of 15.8% and the best line of 16.4%. Our pipeline continues to grow with record year-to-date bookings of 3.1 gigawatts. And the book-to-bill ratio for the year will be greater than 1:1. Potential bookings of 17.4 gigawatts is going approximately 700 megawatts, even as we reported record bookings. Our mid- to late-stage opportunities are also the strongest they've ever been, with 3.9 gigawatts of project. With this, we conclude our prepared remarks and open up the call for questions. Operator?
