componenttext: Great progress on the bookings and cost front. You guys talked about 1-plus gigawatts of bookings beyond 2016? Can you, maybe, just talk a little bit about how you think the margins in the backlog would look like beyond 2016? Can you -- given the efficiency improvement, can you maintain 15-plus percent margins in the systems business beyond 2016 and up?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vishal, I think I made the comment that while we're doing increasing confidence with respect to volumes, I think it's a little early for us to have a firm view on margins. And primarily because with respect to the systems business, that's going to be
componenttext: Yes, Vishal, I think I made the comment that while we're doing increasing confidence with respect to volumes, I think it's a little early for us to have a firm view on margins. And primarily because with respect to the systems business, that's going to be dependent upon ultimate realization of those projects, which is going to depend upon the relevant discount rates and/or cost of capital. And with the dislocation we've seen in markets recently, I think my frank view is that sort of through the end of this year, there's going to be a degree of uncertainty on that. So I don't think we would want to comment. I think as we move into 2016, capital markets should calm down, and we should begin to get some visibility on where those discount rates are going to end up, and that will give us better visibility into the margins on the systems business.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would say, Vishal, is that it is a portion of business on the systems side. Those are projects and have COD that are towards the latter part of this decade, which we've demonstrated with our past that when we are able to get control of a
componenttext: The other thing I would say, Vishal, is that it is a portion of business on the systems side. Those are projects and have COD that are towards the latter part of this decade, which we've demonstrated with our past that when we are able to get control of assets with long-dated contracted period like that with PPAs that are open to the horizon that we've been able to increase significant value of that horizon, as it relates to benefits that we've seen, the reduction of our technology and other assets that we've made. So we feel confident with the long-term margin capture that will capture all of that. It's just a matter of [indiscernible] understanding how cost of capital evolves and how things in the market evolve over the next year or so will probably create a better picture for how we realize margin on those assets out further in the decade.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ben Kallo with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Kallo with Robert W. Baird.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. First, on the YieldCo front, how are you guys viewing the YieldCo at its current price? What can you do to support it? Second, some people will say Stateline helped you on this quarter and the cost cutting is done. Can you just talk a
componenttext: Couple of questions. First, on the YieldCo front, how are you guys viewing the YieldCo at its current price? What can you do to support it? Second, some people will say Stateline helped you on this quarter and the cost cutting is done. Can you just talk about what more you can do to expand margin going forward? I'll leave it there.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ben, this is Mark. I'll take Stateline question and I'll let -- I'll take the YieldCo question and let Jim take the Stateline question, I guess. From a YieldCo standpoint, as we said on the 8.3 call a month or so ago, is both sponsors at this point in tim
componenttext: Ben, this is Mark. I'll take Stateline question and I'll let -- I'll take the YieldCo question and let Jim take the Stateline question, I guess. From a YieldCo standpoint, as we said on the 8.3 call a month or so ago, is both sponsors at this point in time are committed to the drop-downs that we would envision in the first half of '16. We've also indicated that we did not have need to raise capital at this point in time. We've left that in our capacity in 8.3 to manage those anticipated drop-downs with the revolver to later on the term loan the efficiencies that we have embedded in the term structure. So what I would say, we're still moving forward, and we believe we will be able to drop down those assets to the right value equation to the sponsors and create accretions to 8.3. We'll continue to evaluate how the equity trades over time and will continue to assess how we would structure assets beyond the first half of '16, as we said before, we may live to put leverage on these assets, which would then allow us to create a leverage yield to the 8.3 shareholder that is accretive. so there's other structuring options that we do have, that we're continuing to look at. But beyond the first half of '16, we would say we're committed on the drop-downs. We'll continue to evaluate from the market and ensure that the drop-downs makes sense in the latter half of '16.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And on the other -- clearly, we benefited from a project that's been part of the portfolio for a long time, and everybody's known about the operational performance. This quarter clearly extends well beyond that. That clearly had no impact upon the bo
componenttext: Yes. And on the other -- clearly, we benefited from a project that's been part of the portfolio for a long time, and everybody's known about the operational performance. This quarter clearly extends well beyond that. That clearly had no impact upon the bookings side of the equation, which was the strongest quarter in our history from that standpoint. In terms of can we continue to drive margin and competitiveness through cost reductions, as I have stated regularly that the religion around here and we have a cost road map that we remain committed to, that extends well beyond where we are today, we've never backed away from that roadmap and we've continued to hit the road map that we laid out several years ago. Further, we continue to spend robustly on R&D, and we continue to build opportunities that will allow that roadmap to extend beyond the commitments that we have today, particularly outside of the module and into the balance of system. And then at the corporate level, we continue to have a focus on growing the business while, at the same time, getting leaner. And so, we want to see our OpEx come down, not only on a unit basis, but also on an aggregate basis. And so given how radically we've changed the business, the fact that we've maintained cost control from an OpEx standpoint, I think is a notable accomplishment for the organization. So there's no doubt on our part that we have the ability to continue to drive competitiveness and not in some narrow fashion, but broadly across the entire business, being very reflective of the decision to be vertically integrated and to give us the ability to target all aspects of the value chain.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would say is that if you look at it, we took the guidance up, as we indicated, by about $1.35 or so, and that's the operational. None of that $0.35 had anything to do with Stateline. So if you want to look at it discretely, we've always
componenttext: The other thing I would say is that if you look at it, we took the guidance up, as we indicated, by about $1.35 or so, and that's the operational. None of that $0.35 had anything to do with Stateline. So if you want to look at it discretely, we've always said that there's been lumpiness around the timing of revenue recognition in the systems business, and particularly, if we look at it, say, there was strength in the quarter supported by Stateline, but as it relates to the upside to the year, the operational benefit is not reflective of Stateline.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Will hear next from Paul Coster with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Will hear next from Paul Coster with JP Morgan.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 3 questions, unrelated. I'll just throw them in at the same time. The first one relates to the business you're starting to see in the southeast, and particularly, U.S. projects that you might be seeing post 2016. What's driving it? Is it state-leve
componenttext: I have 3 questions, unrelated. I'll just throw them in at the same time. The first one relates to the business you're starting to see in the southeast, and particularly, U.S. projects that you might be seeing post 2016. What's driving it? Is it state-level rags? Is it renewable portfolio standards? Is it still replacement? Is it some combination we will see about? And then the other question is you're obviously taking a break on upgrading the capacity, because you're fully deployed. Does this also mean that we see a sort of break in the progress in terms of energy efficiency? Will you at the end of the hiatus come back and there will be a stat improvement in line efficiency at that point?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll tackle the first, the Southeast. I think there's a broad set of reasons. It has less to do with state rags and more to do with cost structures getting down to a point where they represent a compelling value within the energy mix in that part of the c
componenttext: I'll tackle the first, the Southeast. I think there's a broad set of reasons. It has less to do with state rags and more to do with cost structures getting down to a point where they represent a compelling value within the energy mix in that part of the country. As I have consistently said, there's a broad awakening on the part of utilities to the value that solar represents, and in particular, as they look forward to the clean power plant, as they look forward to constraints on the ability to operate existing coal plants or construct new coal plants, they see an increasing shift towards natural gas and, accordingly, a significant exposure to natural gas commodities. And while natural gas is very, very inexpensive today, everybody remains cautious and worried about future increases in that commodity. So it's broadly the ability to diversify their generation mix into a technology that is cost effective and affordable in the context of today's prices and also offers a significant hedge against future commodity prices. I think that it's that broad package of characteristics that is really what is compelling people to procure utilities, in particular, to include probable take in their generation mix. Your other question?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is on the efficiency.
componenttext: Is on the efficiency.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the efficiency. So there won't be a step function because when we, again, begin applying -- we will continue to be working. We're continuously working from an R&D standpoint. So when it comes to implementation of each new advance, you can't initiate it
componenttext: On the efficiency. So there won't be a step function because when we, again, begin applying -- we will continue to be working. We're continuously working from an R&D standpoint. So when it comes to implementation of each new advance, you can't initiate it across the entire fleet at the same time, and you also -- we are also very cautious about implementing too many advances in a single moment, because you have a great deal of difficulty. It's more challenging to track and determine that it is performing at production scale, exactly the way you anticipate it and to make sure that from a quality standpoint, you're delivering what you promised. So there's a risk management aspect to how many new advantage you throw into each iteration of the product. So you will see it must go from flat to back to a relatively steep curve in terms of the advances, but I wouldn't describe it as a step function.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Krish Sankar with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Krish Sankar with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. Good job on execution and numbers for the quarter. I'm just kind of wondering, the focus to go more international, is it part of the reason because the development in landscape has cooled off a bit in the U.S? And if so, or if not so, what
componenttext: Two quick ones. Good job on execution and numbers for the quarter. I'm just kind of wondering, the focus to go more international, is it part of the reason because the development in landscape has cooled off a bit in the U.S? And if so, or if not so, what are the primary reason and what kind of returns or margins do you expect on these international projects?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The reason for going international is that the last 2.5 decades and understanding the power industry had taught me that the power industry tends to be cyclical on a regional basis. Often times, those cycles tend to be non-correlated. And if you want to bu
componenttext: The reason for going international is that the last 2.5 decades and understanding the power industry had taught me that the power industry tends to be cyclical on a regional basis. Often times, those cycles tend to be non-correlated. And if you want to build a smooth, steadier business profile, you need to participate in multiple geographies, multiple economies, so that you have the ability to shift to whatever happens to be the area of greatest need. So it's less about the U.S. and more about the desire to grow, the desire to diversify to markets in which we can play. It also speaks to the fact that as our product has improved, as our efficiency has improved, as our spectral response has improved, we're just increasingly competitive across the broader set of geographies, and that makes it possible for us to go out and compete in these geographies. So it's not one single discrete reason. It's part of a broader strategy to build what we believe will be a robust, growing and steady business in the future.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think just the other one question you had on the returns. I'd look at it as the portfolio. So in every region, every market has its own unique, I'll call it margin in Thailand portfolio. Solar in general turns to [indiscernible] computing terms of alter
componenttext: I think just the other one question you had on the returns. I'd look at it as the portfolio. So in every region, every market has its own unique, I'll call it margin in Thailand portfolio. Solar in general turns to [indiscernible] computing terms of alternative sources of energy. Other dynamics around how competitive our technology may be in a specific market, given high climate conditions, given humidity, given spectral response, given fused lights. So if you look at it from a portfolio standpoint and you'll find in some markets, the returns that we would see are multiple, higher than what we would see here in the U.S. So some markets, there may be lower than what we see in the U.S., but on average, I would say that we're finding very robust returns and that are comparable and generally could be stronger than U.S., again you have to look at it on a market-by-market basis though.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next is Jon Windham with Barclays.
componenttext: Next is Jon Windham with Barclays.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just quickly, I don't want to put words in your mouth, but I think you'd raised 2015 EPS guidance by about $1, and you said $0.35 of that was related to operational efficiency, cost cutting. Am I right to assume that the other $0.65 is related to Statelin
componenttext: Just quickly, I don't want to put words in your mouth, but I think you'd raised 2015 EPS guidance by about $1, and you said $0.35 of that was related to operational efficiency, cost cutting. Am I right to assume that the other $0.65 is related to Stateline?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, the other -- so what that is the other, and it's actually $0.60. I think that we said approximately $1. So I think the actual midpoint is probably $0.95, but $0.60 is the end-of-life obligation liability change. So based on the change in estimate, if
componenttext: No, the other -- so what that is the other, and it's actually $0.60. I think that we said approximately $1. So I think the actual midpoint is probably $0.95, but $0.60 is the end-of-life obligation liability change. So based on the change in estimate, if you tax effect that benefit, it's around $0.60. The other $0.35 is just through operational performance, in about $0.20 or so -- $0.25 of it shipped up in cost of goods sold as we're seeing continued improvements around cost a lot. Our engineering EPC business and our overall ability to drive cost out of our balance of system is improving better than we have anticipated. And then as Jim indicated, we are increasingly focused on managing our operating expenses. So we brought that down by about another $0.10 or so. So it's a combination of great performance around manufacturing EPC and then managing our operating expenses.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe if I can ask ...
componenttext: And maybe if I can ask ...

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next we'll hear from Sven Eenmaa with Stifel.
componenttext: Next we'll hear from Sven Eenmaa with Stifel.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to ask in terms of the commercial and industrial markets. What are you seeing there, or what are the prospects there for you guys in '16 and '17? And second, in terms of your cost road map toward $1 a watt, what are the biggest levers here
componenttext: First, I wanted to ask in terms of the commercial and industrial markets. What are you seeing there, or what are the prospects there for you guys in '16 and '17? And second, in terms of your cost road map toward $1 a watt, what are the biggest levers here beyond the module cost reductions?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, on the commercial and industrial front, we do have some customers that are integrators and developers that will use our modules on commercial and industrial roots. Obviously, it's not a gigantic focus, but there are some volumes. I think on ground
componenttext: First, on the commercial and industrial front, we do have some customers that are integrators and developers that will use our modules on commercial and industrial roots. Obviously, it's not a gigantic focus, but there are some volumes. I think on ground now with commercial and industrial, we see a robust set of opportunity. It's very hard for us to differentiate in the sales chain with a lot of our developers between utility, direct purchases and purchases that are bilateral to commercial and industrial customers. That -- those 2 business classes can feel exactly the same to us. There's not a big distinction, but we know there is a fair bit of it out there in the contracts that have been booked and signed recently. In terms of what levers do we pull other than the module. It's the balance of system, and it's all aspects of the balance of system, from the structures to materials to material costs to the means and methods of construction. There are -- when you look across labor and materials, they are both significant contributors to the balance of system costs, and we are spending a lot of time and effort on reducing labor, not just in terms of labor rates, but actually changing the means and methods of construction to reduce the number of actions and amount of time it takes to install, and reducing materials on the rest of the balance of systems. So it's all about the balance of system when you get past the module.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the other thing just to point out in that regard, though, is that the balance of system is synergistic to the module. So as we drive up the efficiency of the module effectively, it reduces the variable balance of system that is needed to install e
componenttext: I think the other thing just to point out in that regard, though, is that the balance of system is synergistic to the module. So as we drive up the efficiency of the module effectively, it reduces the variable balance of system that is needed to install every megawatt of energy that we put into the system. So you can look at as an isolation, but as we continue to drive efficiency, it will naturally drive down the balance of system cost. And that will help us move towards the cost road map that we've laid out.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Patrick Jobin with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Patrick Jobin with Crédit Suisse.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Maheep on behalf of Patrick. Question on third party sales for systems and modules with more supply of projects seeking third-party buyers, instead of being dropped down in the YieldCos, plus pricing dynamics deteriorated in the last few months fo
componenttext: This is Maheep on behalf of Patrick. Question on third party sales for systems and modules with more supply of projects seeking third-party buyers, instead of being dropped down in the YieldCos, plus pricing dynamics deteriorated in the last few months for you?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, clearly, there's a number of YieldCo that had indicated that at this point in time that they don't anticipate being aggressive or acquisitive in looking for projects. In some cases, they've indicated it could be over in the next year, it could be
componenttext: I mean, clearly, there's a number of YieldCo that had indicated that at this point in time that they don't anticipate being aggressive or acquisitive in looking for projects. In some cases, they've indicated it could be over in the next year, it could be longer. But we have, historically, not sold to any YieldCos or traditional tax equity structures, right. We've chosen to partner with -- strategics with tax capacity. So I would say that part of the market is still very robust, as you can see with our ability to sell down Stateline into live with the Southern. Now what that means, though, is that more and more people will be looking to try to engage with the Dominion, the Southern, the Berkshire, you can go down the line, because they may be the most active buyers in the market. And what position of strength that we're in is that we have very strong relationships with a number of those parties. They obviously love the First Solar brand, they love the First Solar relationships, they love the comfort. And so I'm sure that there will be some impact in the market. I think we think we're in a fortunate position, because we have very strong relationship with a number of those parties. But the other thing I would say is that these assets are very attractive. I mean, there's a number of parties that want to have solar assets, long-dated contracted assets with investment-grade counterparties, and the ability to acquire or that will come to market in '16 relative to potentially what could be in the market in '17 and '18 is there's a window that may be closing in terms of the number of projects that can be acquired. And I would expect at least a lot of our traditional buyers strategic [indiscernible] capacity will be very aggressive throughout 2016.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Will hear next from Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.
componenttext: Will hear next from Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So perhaps first quick question. As you think about the international mix here, can you comment about the module versus the developed projects, particularly in the new geographies? And how you think about the incremental margin on those geographies? I kno
componenttext: So perhaps first quick question. As you think about the international mix here, can you comment about the module versus the developed projects, particularly in the new geographies? And how you think about the incremental margin on those geographies? I know you kind of got that a little bit before, but are you thinking about these? Have you added new contracts as being truly development opportunities or to the most part, should we be thinking about, especially India has more of a module or module plus kind of opportunity? And then perhaps as a second unrelated question, I'll throw it out there now, the Southeast activity, et cetera, is that -- how much of that is EPP driven and how much of an overhang is the early action credit being all the way out in 2020 limiting procurement? Just wanted to get your thoughts on that.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's step back to development on the international side. So each -- we look at each market discreetly. One of the, I think, learnings over the last several years is that you cannot generalize about -- even within the same region, even neighboring coun
componenttext: So let's step back to development on the international side. So each -- we look at each market discreetly. One of the, I think, learnings over the last several years is that you cannot generalize about -- even within the same region, even neighboring countries, often times you can't generalize about what the business mix for us is going to look like. So the way we think about development is, if we do development, we want to get paid for it. And when we say that, what that means is that we want to earn a return that's above and beyond whatever we believe the margin or module plus type of entitlement would be, if we're going to engage in the development process. And there are markets where we go and we see the opportunity to get paid for being the developer. And there are markets where we absolutely do not see that opportunity. So when you look across the world, Japan is a market where we have felt that we can get paid for being the developer, and we are very active in the development. India is a market where we feel we can get paid for being a developer, and we are at this as a developer. What's difference is there are capital constraints in India that don't exist in other markets. There is a limits how much development we're going to be able to do, so we also are very aggressive on the module and module plus fronts in India. As we look at new and different markets around the world, there is an initial process that it takes us a little while to get on the ground and spend enough time in the markets to really figure out whether there is an entitlement that is going to justify development. I think it's fair to say that at this point, our method of operation is let's lead with the module. And then, as we begin to establish the market share, get some resource on the ground and get a greater understanding of the market, we'll look hard at whether we think there is a development opportunity. But I don't think you can generalize. I don't think you could say all of the incremental demand internationally is going to be module only. That's certainly not what we're thinking about it. But I also think it's safe to say, it's not all going to be development. Development is OpEx and census. It is always complicated in a new market. And so we can only take on so many new markets at a time without driving our OpEx to unacceptable levels. And so, it's going to be a balance between -- okay, let's take the OpEx resources that we chose to live within and let's apply those in the markets we're going to get greater saving [ph] for our work from a development standpoint. And then, let's go with a lesser stealth [ph] in other markets where we can capture market share on an OpEx like basis, admittedly, at probably lower margins, but still accretive to the overall outcome for the company.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next we'll hear from Brian Lee with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next we'll hear from Brian Lee with Goldman Sachs.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Hancock [ph] on for Brian. My question was around nat gas prices and the trend we've seen in the recent months. How is that impacting the pricing discussion that you are having with customers for U.S. projects that could be potentially 2017 or '18
componenttext: This is Hancock [ph] on for Brian. My question was around nat gas prices and the trend we've seen in the recent months. How is that impacting the pricing discussion that you are having with customers for U.S. projects that could be potentially 2017 or '18. I think there's a belief that PPA prices might go up in '17 with the ITC, but what does lower gas do to that?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quite frankly, the front [indiscernible] of natural gas doesn't really enter into the discussions. All of our conversations in the U.S. are 25, 15 -- between 15- and 30-year PPAs. So the utilities are looking at -- in their integrated resource planning an
componenttext: Quite frankly, the front [indiscernible] of natural gas doesn't really enter into the discussions. All of our conversations in the U.S. are 25, 15 -- between 15- and 30-year PPAs. So the utilities are looking at -- in their integrated resource planning and their long-term curves. And I don't think their longer term analysis has changed. If you assume that these low prices are going to pull rig counts down, when you look at the production cost and stack up the patience against that production cost, I think everybody gets to the same kind of level when you get out 5 to 10 years, and that is the point on the curve that is more impactful. If you got to a position in the United States where people believe that $2, $2.50 gas prices were going to be the norm for the next 15 years, then I think that might change the discussion. But I don't think that's what people have in their mind at this point.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Shawn Yuan for Mahesh. On the Stateline project, I just want to look across some other transactions that the company has done, typically daily requirement or [indiscernible] tax equity benefit. I just wonder if it's the same arrangement, maybe you
componenttext: This is Shawn Yuan for Mahesh. On the Stateline project, I just want to look across some other transactions that the company has done, typically daily requirement or [indiscernible] tax equity benefit. I just wonder if it's the same arrangement, maybe you can share more details on the transaction? And then as a follow-up. The minority interest in the Stateline project, is still planned to be drop-down to 8.3?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way we structured Stateline is very comparable to the way that we structured some of our other assets where we sold the majority interest. So the structure is the same. Again, the tax aspects will be monetized. 51% of the cash flows go with the majori
componenttext: The way we structured Stateline is very comparable to the way that we structured some of our other assets where we sold the majority interest. So the structure is the same. Again, the tax aspects will be monetized. 51% of the cash flows go with the majority owner and then the 49% of the cash flows would come to First Solar, and again, that's over the flipped horizon after the flipped horizon that the tax and the cash are split the same way. At this point in time, we've -- Stateline is a [indiscernible] asset for 8.3, and we anticipate to achieve COD for Stateline in Q3 of '16. We'll continue to evaluate the market assuming that the market economics makes sense, and that would be the incentive. What we would do is that we would drop Stateline at 8.3.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's conference. Thank you for your participation.
